<DIV></DIV>&gt;Message: 6 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;From: "Sriram Krishnan" &lt;ksriram@gmx.net&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;To: "'Sudharsan.S.N.'" &lt;sudharsan@rediffmail.com&gt;, 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &lt;ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Cc: &lt;sridharinfinity@yahoo.com&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Subject: RE: [Ilugc] Are you serious? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Date: Thu, 1 Apr 2004 20:05:53 +0530 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;I've been thinking about my replies to this thread and I think I've been 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;guilty of confusing two separate things - Linux as a product and the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;whole philosophy behind OSS. So I thought I'd split my arguments from 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;now on.... 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;First of all, Linux (the product) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;---------------------------------- 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;Trying to say UIs are bad in all OSS is a spurious argument in itself. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;It all depends upon the user, and present day if u consider 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;proprietary Windows and OSS Linux the UI does not differ to the 'bad' 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;extent. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Usually, sweeping generalizations are bad form. But in this case , I 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;think I'm more than justified. Apart from the Mozilla guys, I can't say 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;that there is a single OSS project out there that dedicates itself to 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;usability. Do understand that usability does not mean adding a bunch of 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;wizards to your software as an afterthought. People like Microsoft and 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Apple have whole labs (buildings with hundreds of people) working on 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;usability....measuring,testing,imporoving,etc. Do you think Google would 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;be where it is today without the help of Jacob Nielsen? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;I find it interesting that you say that the GUI doesn't differ from 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Windows to Linux. Though MS licensed a lot of GUI concepts (like 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;overlapped windows) from Apple and Xerox, stuff like the start button is 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;solely a MS innovation. And what do I see today? Both Gnome and KDE 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;shamelessly ripping them off...In fact , nowadays, both KDE and Gnome 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;look like a skinned version of Windows. Where is the innovation? Soon, 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;MS will come out with Longhorn(which has a mind-blowing interface...I've 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;been lucky enough to see sneak previews which are not available on the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;net). Where is the corresponding OSS plan? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;GUI is a concept and a technology in itself and trying to say that GUIs 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;in OSS are 'bad' very well applies to Windows which also believes &gt;that 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;GUI is the best thing promoting it`s 'quality'. Trying to compare two 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;OSs on the same technology of GUI and saying one is 'bad' isn`t &gt;a 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;healthy argument in itself. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Why not? I was comparing the ease-of-use of both Oss and I found the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;GUIs as the easiest barometer. As for CUIs, you're right...Linux kicks 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Windows' behind. However, that'll soon change with Longhorn (google for 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Monad) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;I think IBM and Sun know better abt this than both of us do - They r 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;talking abt freedom to tweak with ur code 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Tell me...has IBM released the source to DB2? Or Sun its Java 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;implementation? Sun and IBM want to get involved with Linux purely 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;because that's the only hope they have of competing with MS. You would 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;be deceiving yourself if you though they really believed in the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;principles of OSS. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;Tell me one company which has reverse migrated bcos it hasnt found the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;performance of Linux/OSS satisfactory!! But as for all the other 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;migrating stories, u`ll be hearing it all over!! 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;I didn't have to look far.Just read the thread titled 'Success story' on 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;this group a few days back :-) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;What r they going to do with the several TBs of errors resulting due to 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;OS problems? Trying to say Win is error-free wud be a big joke!! 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;Linux handles almost all such things u have mentioned with a simple msg 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;which prevents u from carrying on further than let the whole 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;platform on which all the applications r resting to crash and having to 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;do the 'holy' act of restarting the system. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;They analyze the errors. They figure out what is causing the errors. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;They look at ways of fixing it ( a lot of which is making its way into 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;SP2). Saying that Win is error-free is a joke...but so is saying the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;same thing about Linux. About the error message, I'm not sure whether 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;you've seen XP. XP pops up a message box about whether you want to 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;report the error(and users have the option of turning off this 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;notification) and then shuts down the app. You get the 'Abort,Retry..' 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;message only if you have a debugger like Visual Studio installed on your 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;comp. When was the last time you saw a blue-screen with XP(mind 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;you...you should have MS-certified drivers. I don't think even Linux can 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;do much about bad kernel-level stuff). I once wrote an app to allocate 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;over 2gb of memory(in small increments). It took a long time ...,but XP 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;was stable once I shut down the app. Don't compare the 9x series with 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;2k,XP or 2003. These new Windows based on the NT kernel are rock-solid. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Now, for Linux - the process(FSF,GNU, Bazaar et. al) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;----------------------------------------------------------------- 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;You feel having the source code as an Engineer it`s a luxury but the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;whole of the OSS community and even the programming world wud 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;consider it as a requirement. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;The OSS world - yes. The programming world - no. Tell me, why don't you 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;ask Intel or AMD to give up their processor making technology? Why apply 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;a different barometer to MS? Or why don't you ask IBM to give up the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;source code to DB2? Why go after MS alone? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;By debugging other`s code u can see what`s essentially wrong, what is 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;right, what can be done!! Anyway OSS programmer are not debuggers. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;They dont get error reports and debug their previous versions and 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;re-release them under a new 'jilpans' name. All people in the OSS 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;community are rightly credited and they r as famous as the tool they 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;have developed or contributed to. They get their due share of name and 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;fame and r not unpaid programmers. They get their share of fame and &gt;are 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;paid well. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Now, you really got me wrong here. I never called OSS developers as 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;'debuggers'( if I did,a couple of friends of mine in the Bangalore LUG 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;would chop my head off :-)) . I'm saying that the scope for employment 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;developing so-called proprietary code is much higher. I want to ask the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;people on this group...how many of you make a living by *developing* OSS 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;software? No, administering a Linux network/server doesn't count. How 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;many of us can be like Miguel Icacza and get paid by Novell? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;As for people making money of OSS, I want to point you to another raging 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;thread on this very thread....where someone asked about making money off 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;the GPL...and people advised him to use some other license ! Say you've 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;spent two years with a team of 20-30 people developing an app. You make 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;it open-source...and then bang! Some one else comes along....takes your 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;code...makes a few modifications and starts making money. How do you 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;prevent that? 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt; The Godforsaken code had to be leaked and not given out fairly to the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;programming community. This seems to prove the point. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;What point? That code has now been in the open for almost a month and 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;I'm sure thousands of people have looked at it. And all they've found is 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;one vulnerability in IE which had been fixed 3 years ago. In fact, there 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;was an article on www.kuro5hin.org reluctantly admitting that the code 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;was of very high quality. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;When I say innovation I very specifically mean what lies beyond the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;available domain 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Do plug-ins or the hundreds of other extensibility mechanisms. You 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;mentioned the Lens filter in Adobe Photoshop. Well, Photoshop exposes a 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;plug-in mechanism which lets you write your own filters and what not. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;And I could go on for years about .NET's extensibility and flexibility. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Yes, I'm sure that there are a few fringe cases where the extensibility 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;mechanisms won't be sufficient. But I perfectly understand Microsoft not 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;wanting to expose their work(which has cost them a LOT of time and 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;money) for this miniscule minority ( If you disagree, I would like you 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;to show some stats proving that this is not miniscule). 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;OSS is not against MS company and Bill gates` fortune, it`s against the 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;"MS policies" which does not allow a user/programmer to do what he 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;wants. Well, that just sums up 'our' OSS policy. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Ok....2 things here. One, like I've already repeated ad nauseum, why not 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;ask IBM to let you work on the code to one of their software? Or ask AMD 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;to let you help out with their technology? Why pick on MS? If MS is so 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;evil, why haven't they sued the Mono guys yet? (who implement not only 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;the ECMA part of .NET but also a lot of MS - patented stuff) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Two, I would really like some examples of *mainstream* Linux 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;modifications not possible with Windows not possible due to the lack of 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;source code. This is the core disagreement...whether the source is 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;necessary for the average user/programmer or even if it is necessary for 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;the majority of the users. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;OSS programmer are not people in Tirumala Tirupathi Devasthanam who do 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;honorary work - they r very much programmers who program every day &gt;for 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;their daily bread 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Please see the other thread on this group regarding making money using 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;the GPL. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;But be magnanimous enough to accept that the OSS programmers are also 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;'great' programmers and not 'debuggers' as u had said. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;I never said that!!! If I met Eric.S.Raymond on the street tomm, I would 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;be too speechless to even pull out my autograph book :-) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;OSS programmers are just as good as any other programmers. The question 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;here is on philosophy...not on skill or talent. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; &gt;Anyway this has definitely been a good quality argument where newbies 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;have come to know so many things!! 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Finally,...something we both agree on :-) 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Anyway, I think a debate between Windows vs Linux is pointless. The 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;answer always lies in how good the user is and what the task required 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;is. You are right when you say that you and I are not going to end this 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;debate here. Anyway, I'm not comfortable with talking about Windows on a 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Linux user group...off-topic posting is never good. If you remember, 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;this thread started because somebody posted some wrong information about 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;MS presence in Chennai colleges...I never wanted it to get into a 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;traditional MS vs Linux debate. If anybody feels offended, I apologize.. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt; 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;As for the argument regarding the philosophy, I believe the core 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;question is one of IP (Intellectual Property ) rights. MS believes that 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;you use what you've developed however you want...make money if you want 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;to...keep it to yourself if you want to. That's&nbsp;&nbsp;the core difference 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;here. 
<DIV></DIV>&gt;

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Apr  1 17:28:11 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu, 01 Apr 2004 22:58:11 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Are you serious?
In-Reply-To: <Law10-F4IMyQ5xyoE9k00024b7f@hotmail.com>
References: <Law10-F4IMyQ5xyoE9k00024b7f@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <406C512B.4080709@frodo.hserus.net>

please don't hit reply and quote the full digest

There is a lot wrong with windows, but your argument in this case 
doesn't hold good.

[4/1/2004 10:47 PM]  Balaji G :

> "When was the last time you saw a blue-screen with XP(mind you...you 
> should have MS-certified drivers." Who is MS to certify the drivers. why 
> should MS certify a driver which has already passed the test done by the 
> developer of that driver under windows. This shows that MS likes 
> Monopoly (Dont Flame me ) and ppl who dont have the hardware certified 

what do you mean?

suppose I contribute a module to the linux kernel for (say) some sort of 
USB camera.  and suppose I am the manufacturer of that usb camera.

if I submit that module to the kernel, do you think it will be accepted 
on blind faith, without any quality control / checking by the kernel 
maintainers?

> we saw BSOD in XP but it was quite different from 98 :-)). An Operating 
> System should be developed keeping in mind that the customer might use 
> any branded hardware and once if the customer installs the driver for 
> that hardware the Operating system should support it thats it .Assume 

Try installing a linux module for say ethernet card that the 
manufacturer shipped in the install CD.  Even if it is source code, you 
may well have problems setting that up on any kernel other than the one 
the guy developed the driver on.

	srs

From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Thu Apr  1 18:01:19 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Thu, 01 Apr 2004 23:31:19 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Are you serious
Message-ID: <406C58EF.105@md4.vsnl.net.in>

,----[Sriram Krishnan <ksriram@gmx.net>]
| "What principles? A lot of universities and companies have access to
| Windows code as well as a lot of governments. I'm surprised that you've
| heard some derogatory comments about FSF/GNU...can you tell us when and
| where this was? And even in the case it actually happened, do you mean
| to say that there are no derogatory comments about MS here? Do
| understand that MS consists of over 55,000 people...a lot of different
| viewpoints. However, let me tell you...EVERY SINGLE MS employee I've met
| runs some Linux distro at home without letting his employer know. Do
| read what I just said...those guys are just as much hackers as anybody
| in the OSS community. If MS didn't support these principles, how do you
| explain www.gotdotnet.com workspaces or www.sscli.net. Or all the .NET
| projects on SF?
`----
 
Free software  gives the freedom to  use both the object  code and the
source code.  Disclosing  the source code under a  tight and stringent
copyright  license is  quite different  from distributing  source code
with freedom to study, copy, modify, and redistribute.
 
You are  a Student Ambassador  of Microsoft and an  Official Microsoft
representative, and one  need not expect you to  understand or support
free  software  licenses or  principles,  and  instead,  you could  be
expected to  promote the  profits and business  of Microsoft  in every
possible by even writing non-stop  nonsense to a gnu/linux user group.
One  can know  about principles  from  the licenses  and other  public
reports, and misstatements don't help anybody.  

,----[Sriram Krishnan <ksriram@gmx.net>]
| Now, let me ask you this...let's say SCO wins its case against IBM and
| the existence of SCO code in Linux is proven ? Then what happens? Does
| everybody go start work on Hurd? Or do they pay a lot of money to SCO?
| What happens to the OSS community then when their kernel is yanked from
| under their feet? Now, I know that the answer is a resounding yes..that
| the OSS community would still survive. Now, how doesn't this apply to my
| (and related groups)?
`----
 
You won't  have heard of FreeBSD,  NetBSD or OpenBSD.
 
You  won't have  heard  of the  European  Commission's recent  rulings
against Microsoft.  What if all the rest of the countries in the world
take serious  note of it, and  take more stringent  action, that would
wipe out Microsoft  and where will you be after  that. You are welcome
to join the free software movement with an open heart before it is too
late :)                
----------

| answerable to  me..what's to stop him  from ditching me  one fine day?
| Here, I can  sue MS or some  other vendor. With the GPL,  I can't even
| hold anybody legally responsible.
`----

well, for out  of the box support, yes many  open source companies are
trying to give good support. Redhat  is one such company that comes to
my  mind. Agree, the  support quality  is far  worse than  what larger
companies like Microsoft  can offer. Support would improve  (at a much
more faster pace than you think!) as the wave catches up.

,----
| I don't see anything other  than trivial difference. Both of them know
| their areas of  expertise really well. Both know  how to trouble-shoot
| problems.  Both are  really passionate  about the  stuff they  do. And
| people here DO know how  most stuff works on the inside...just because
| you don't have access to source  code doesn't mean that you don't know
| how a system works. So tell me...where's the difference?
`----

The difference  is adding a  nice new feature  / fixing a  bug without
having to wait  for the next 'hotfix' all by  asking people. (ok, now,
I'm not expecting a  patching-the-binary argument. I'm sure I wouldn't
be able to find a patch-the-IIS-binary guy in chennai as easily (read:
economically) as  I would find  an above-average-IQed C  programmer to
fix a simple my bug)

cheers,

  -Suraj

| There are more than 10 trillion living cells in the human body.
`------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Thu Apr  1 18:24:30 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Thu, 01 Apr 2004 23:54:30 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Workshop on Open Access to Scientific Literature at MSSRF
Message-ID: <406C5E5E.4080602@md4.vsnl.net.in>

----- Forwarded message from Sunil Abraham <sunil@mahiti.org> -----

 > Date: Thu, 01 Apr 2004 12:33:02 +0000
 > From: Sunil Abraham <sunil@mahiti.org>
 > Subject: [Commons-Law] Workshop on Open Access/E-Prints Software
 > To: Commons Law <commons-law@sarai.net>
 > X-Mailer: Ximian Evolution 1.4.5
 >
 > Dear friends:
 >
 > Greetings from MSSRF, Chennai.
 >
 > Here is an announcement about a workshop on Open Access to scientific
 > and scholarly literature and an application form. Please spread the
 > word. Preference will be givn to candidates from large universities,
 > INDEST institutions and government laboratories (CSIR, ICAR, ICMR, DAE,
 > DST, etc.).
 >
 > Please forward this announcement to heads of institutions and heads of
 > libraries in all institutions in the areas of social sciences and
 > humanities.
 >
 > They may send their nominations/ applications to Mr S Senthilkumaran,
 > Associate Director, Informatics, MSSRF, Chennai 600 113, before 10 April
 > 2004. His email address: <senthil@mssrf.res.in>.
 >
 > Look forward to hearing from you. Best wishes.
 >
 > Subbiah Arunachalam
 > Distinguished Fellow, MSSRF
 > -------
 >
 >
 >
 > Workshop on Open Access
 >
 > Overview
 >
 > All scientists, including social scientists, need to publish their
 > findings. Indeed, research is incomplete as long as it remains
 > unpublished. The last few years have witnessed the unprecedented rise in
 > the subscription costs of journals and even well-endowed institutions in
 > rich countries find it difficult to retain journal subscriptions. The
 > situation in developing countries like India is even worse. Besides,
 > others in the rest of the world do not really read much of the work that
 > we do in India. What is more, if our scientists publish their papers in
 > expensive journals, then even other Indian scientists do not read them,
 > as not many Indian institutions may subscribe to those journals. It is
 > for this reason that the open access (OA) movement is gaining ground
 > around the world - both in the advanced countries and in the developing
 > countries. Indeed, OA will be of much greater advantage to India than to
 > the western countries.
 >
 > Physicists have been placing their preprints and postprints for well
 > over 13 years in a centralized archive called arXiv, which has more than
 > 15 mirror sites including one located in India (Matscience, Chennai).
 > There are several other services such as Cogprints (for cognitive
 > sciences), CiteSeer (for computer science) and RePEc (for economics).
 > Currently, institutional archives are favoured, as they work to satisfy
 > the felt needs of both individual scientists and their institutions.
 > There are at least three sets of software available, all of them free,
 > to set up such interoperable institutional archives. This workshop aims
 > to help Indian scientists (representing general and agricultural
 > universities and government laboratories under the various councils and
 > departments) to acquire the skills necessary to be able to set up and
 > maintain institutional open archives. This workshop will provide
 > training in Eprints software developed at the University of Southampton
 > and the Open Archives Interoperability protocol.
 >
 > There is great interest in open access around the world. In the USA,
 > Congressman Martin Sabo has introduced a bill suggesting that findings
 > of all publicly funded research must be made freely available to all. In
 > the UK, the Parliament has appointed a committee to inquire current and
 > potentially useful practices in science publishing. Several discussion
 > lists are actively promoting exchange of views on open access. The
 > Budapest Open Access Initiative is providing funds to promote open
 > access initiatives.
 >
 > In India, INSA devoted a whole day for a seminar on open access at its
 > annual meeting held at NCL, Pune, in late December 2003. Indian Academy
 > of Sciences, Bangalore, held two workshops on open access journals in
 > March 2002.
 >
 > The Workshop
 >
 > On a suggestion from Prof. M S Valiathan, President of the Indian
 > National Science Academy, the Bioinformatics Centre of the M S
 > Swaminathan Research Foundation will be holding two identical three-day
 > workshops with a view to developing a cadre of open access experts in
 > Indian higher educational institutions and government laboratories. We
 > expect that before the end of the year at least a dozen institutions
 > will have their own institutional archives up and running. There will be
 > 20-24 participants in each workshop. Each participant and the faculty
 > will have an Internet-connected computer on his/her desk.
 >
 > Dates: 2-4 May 2004 and 6-8 May 2004
 >
 > Venue:  M S Swaminathan Research Foundation, Sambasivan Auditorium
 >
 > The Faculty: The workshop will be conducted by the following four
 > experts, known for their commitment to promoting this technology
 > worldwide: Prof. Leslie Chan of the University of Toronto and Bioline
 > International, Dr Leslie Carr of the University of Southampton, Dr D K
 > Sahu of MedKnow Publications, Mumbai, and Dr T B Rajashekar of the
 > Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore. All of them have considerable
 > hands-on experience in open access.
 >
 > Participants: Higher educational institutions and government research
 > laboratories (under the different Councils and Departments) may nominate
 > candidates in the prescribed form. [Heads of these institutions may
 > kindly ensure that an institutional archive is set up within three
 > months after the conclusion of the workshop]. 4048 candidates will be
 > selected. Participants will either be scientists or be librarians. The
 > important thing is they should be computer savvy and committed to the
 > cause of open access and be able to persuade scientists (faculty and
 > students) in their respective institutions to place their research
 > papers in the archives.
 >
 > Guest speakers: We are inviting Prof. M S Swaminathan, Prof. M S
 > Valiathan, Dr R A Mashelkar and Prof. P Balaram to give guest lectures
 > (on how they, as working scientists, view open access). Two of them will
 > address the participants of the first workshop and the other two the
 > second workshop.
 >
 > Workshop Coordinator: Subbiah Arunachalam, Distinguished Fellow, MSSRF,
 > Chennai. His email address is <arun@mssrf.res.in>. Mr S Senthilkumaran
 > and colleagues from the Informatics Division and Ms R V Bhavani of MSSRF
 > will provide technical and managerial support for the event.
 >
 > Nominations of participants may please be sent to Mr S Senthilkumaran,
 > Associate Director, Informatics, MSSRF, Chennai 600 113, India. His
 > email address is <senthil@mssrf.res.in>.
 >
 > All participants will be provided guesthouse accommodation and all
 > meals. A few travel grants (First class or Second A/C class by Express
 > train) will be made available, depending on funds available.
 >
 > Some Relevant Documents
 > The Bethesda Statement
 > http://www.earlham.edu/~peters/fos/bethesda.htm
 > http://www.earlham.edu/~peters/fos/bethesda.htm>
 >
 > Wellcome Trust, "Scientific Publishing: A Position Statement by the
 > Wellcome Trust in Support of Open Access Publishing,"
 >
 > <http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/en/1/awtvispolpub.html
 > <http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/en/1/awtvispolpub.html>
 >
 > Berlin Declaration on Open Access to Knowledge in the Sciences and
 > Humanities
 > <http://www.zim.mpg.de/openaccess-berlin/berlindeclaration.html
 > <http://www.zim.mpg.de/openaccess-berlin/berlindeclaration.html>
 >
 > Subbiah Arunachalam: India's march towards open access
 > http://www.scidev.net/Opinions/index.cfm?fuseaction=readOpinions
 > 
<http://www.scidev.net/Opinions/index.cfm?fuseaction=readOpinions&itemid=243
 > &language=1> &itemid=243&language=1>
 >

============================================================================================================

>Apart from the Mozilla guys, I can't say
>that there is a single OSS project out there that
dedicates itself to
>usability.

What do you mean? Take a good look at all the other
great tools!!

What r u trying to say, the "My computer" and "Network
neighborhood" make u feel so good and nostalgic abt
MS-Windows GUI and it`s so-called monopolised
usability!!

>Both Gnome and KDE
>shamelessly ripping them off...In fact , nowadays,
both KDE and Gnome
>look like a skinned version of Windows. Where is the
innovation?

I`m trying to tell u that GUI is a concept in which
you have a visual interface comprising of
icons/buttons/windows,etc..........and ur trying to
tell me all of them belong to windows. I`ve studied a
subject called Computer graphics and multimedia - you
have all these visual interfaces well illustrated
there and there is no mention of Windows/Linux. 

My friend, the concept of GUI and all the stuff that
go into it does not belong to Windows. 

Trying to say GUI belong to windows is like saying the
gifts of nature like Basmati/neem belongs to america,
it does not belong to anybody!! It belongs to nature!!
The concept of having a visual representation is GUI
and it cannot belong to people of Microsoft just bocs
they did a wonderful GUI. They might have contributed
but not own it.

You cannot copyright/patent basmati-neem,etc,. They r
nature`s products and trying to say they r yours is
very much of an illegitimate claim. Basmati/Neem
belong to nature and not to india/america/germany.
Even if history wud have been different
someone-somewhere(non-MS) wud have started something
called a GUI only with a menu/pop-up
window/icons/buttons; that is what the subject says
irresptive of the OS used.

Even Solaris has a GUI with menus/buttons/windows, r u
trying to say they copied it from the famous Ms
again?? Forget the wallpapers.......and all those
"jilpans"  screensavers.


>Soon,
>MS will come out with Longhorn(which has a
mind-blowing interface...I've
>been lucky enough to see sneak previews which are not
available on the
>net). Where is the corresponding OSS plan?

You argument favoring MS seems to come more out of
fascination than facts!! You might have to dump ur
processor/monitor/graphics card in the not-so-distant
future, I sure presume u will do that to see the
"Long-Horn". No counter-plan for OSS, just design a
much more friendlier GUI, constant improvisation -as
we call it!!

>Why not? I was comparing the ease-of-use of both Oss
and I found the
>GUIs as the easiest barometer. 

My argument trying to explain ease-of-use was well
illustrated in first reply thread. Ease-of-use depends
on where u start, Windows or Linux!! A person who
starts with "My computer" might find "Home" and the
entire inverted-tree structure annoying and
vice-versa!! When u say ease-of-use, whose
ease-of-use? I dont find any big difference in both
except for some new icons and features in Linux which
r obviously different and difficult, but not because
they r so implicity, but bcos I`m new to them!!
Similarly for u, who must be obviously used to c: and
d: might find '/' and '/root' annoying. 

The difference is perception!! Both r excellent GUIs.
As I had mentioned trying to say GUIs in OSS are bad
is very much spurious in itself!!


>Tell me...has IBM released the source to DB2? Or Sun
its Java
>implementation? Sun and IBM want to get involved with
Linux purely
>because that's the only hope they have of competing
with MS. You would
>be deceiving yourself if you though they really
believed in the
>principles of OSS.

They r not talking abt releasing all their codes of
products which they have released so far, but they r
talking abt becoming open. They r not going to give
away all their past codes( i presume so), but if they
release a product under the banner of OSS(which they r
trying to do) they wud obviously have to release it!!
My argument is not supporting Java/IBM,etc,........My
argument is abt supporting the philosophy of OSS and
not to keep a check on whose releasing it and whose
not. I`m preaching for the doctrines of OSS and not
for Sun/IBM.,etc,.

>They analyze the errors. They figure out what is
causing the errors.
>They look at ways of fixing it 

They have been doing it for decades together!! What is
that going to result in? 
The most-perfect-creation-of-mankind-the-magnum-opus
called Longhorn?? We`ll see that!!

>I once wrote an app to allocate
>over 2gb of memory(in small increments)

Send the code to the group!! Or is it 'taboo'?

>The OSS world - yes. The programming world - no. 

What r U talking abt? The real world/matrix stuff. A
code is a code be it in the "OSS world" or the
"programmers world", a code is a set of lines that
does a specific function.  All r programmers, when
they program, it is essentially lines of code for the
computer to understand. It is only when it comes out
and is shaded with policies such as MS/OSS it becomes
the way u call it!! Essentially speaking, both r lines
of code. What do u see, two different factions??
Programmers do the same work, be it in Red Hat Inc,.
or Microsoft Inc,.,- code!! 

The problem is how it comes out, or whether it ever
comes out or not!!


>Tell me, why don't you
>ask Intel or AMD to give up their processor making
technology? Why apply
>a different barometer to MS? 

When  ur talking abt Intel processors ur talking abt
hardware components and not something u can change the
way u want it to work(of course u can!!). There is a
specific functionality to a device like a processor.
You write assembly language to modify the
functionality not change the design of the processor.
We r not talking abt open source hardware but about
OSS.

>I want to ask the
>people on this group...how many of you make a living
by *developing* OSS
>software? 

What r u trying to say? only people working in MS r
paid. As u urself had pointed out, there r people who
need OSS as a hobby and who r essentially very good
programmers who want to do things or make things
happen with their system. But what r u trying to tell
me, there arent anybody involved in 'paid' OSS work.

>You make
>it open-source...and then bang! Some one else comes
along....takes your
>code...makes a few modifications and starts making
money. How do you
>prevent that?

Let`s analyse the thread that`s running abt this
carefully. Let this "Are you serious" thread go
on.........but keep a watch on that. It is only when a
flower blooms u actually see the beauty behind it!!
(That`s my saying - not the proprietary 'my' - I meant
that I framed it!!) 


>What point? That code has now been in the open for
almost a month and

supports it and u once again say MS is "in" for OSS!!

world know? We r not talking abt code quality anyway!!
We r talking abt code availability!!

My favorite game is still "Age of Empires-Rise of
Rome" and is possibly the best ever; so what??

That MS code was anyway 'leaked' and not bundled with
ur CD!! Anyway I have a question to ask, is ur Windows
XP bought, or just simply 'loaded and installed'? Have
u bought ur Windows XP CD from a "Windows certified
vendor" or just one of ur friend`c CD like almost all
others(including me) and most of them who open this

>But I perfectly understand Microsoft not

What do u mean 'expose'? ur not exposing the Odessa
file!! ur supposedly 'exposing' the code to ur own

paid u money to use ur software!!Forget the

Let me send an "error report" saying I have bought

posts.....pls read them............!!

>this is the core disagreement...whether the source is

>the majority of the users.

This is the core point indeed!! the average user/avg

need it?? Is Ms going to conduct a survey amongst prog
on whether they need code or not? I`ve given a
comparison between a layman/normal user/Engineer, pls
read that again!! 

What abt an Engineer/developer? What abt you? I think
u might not need them............I can c that ur
extremely happy with all that u`ve got from MS, anyway
that`s good news!! Atleast u can R-I-P!!

point to respond to all the threads?? Bcos u want to
prove a point!! So do we!!

If it`s wrong information that Ms is spreading it`s
word on seeing somebody else spread their 'gospel'

>As for the argument regarding the philosophy, I
believe the core
>question is one of IP (Intellectual Property )
rights. MS believes that
>you use what you've developed however you want...make

>to...keep it to yourself if you want to. That's  the
core difference
>here.

Ms does not believe in that choice "if u want to", it
says make money and keep it to urself and don`t treat
the customer as a customer but treat him as a person
who has walked into a dead-end. I know that MS firmly
believes in this!!

The 'best' part abt MS is it doesnt give u too many
choices!!  There r people happy with their choices and
as it goes - "Ignorance is bliss!!" and for the others
they aren`t and Ms obviously does not allow u to even
look at other choices!! The only choices I see are
"Abort/retry/ignore", "Illegal Operation"(the only
allowed choice being 'close'), "Send/Don`t send error
report" and finally "Are you sure you want to
restart?"
I dont mean these choices!! Nor does OSS!!

OSS says, if u believe in the "Ignorance is bliss" go
on just run my programs!! Or else u also can look
beyond what u have, it gives u a choice!! Linux/OSS
does not believe in an outright charity show either!!
Mind you Linux-EL is 99,000/-



>Actually,my mom wonders what in hell I spend so much

I repeat, try to summarize ur views on the "Are you

From ksriram at gmx.net  Thu Apr  1 23:54:42 2004
From: ksriram at gmx.net (Sriram Krishnan)

Hi,
  Finally, we get to the end. Well, I would like all of you to read the
last section of my mail carefully. But first, let me get to responding
some of Sudharshan's points

>Trying to say GUI belong to windows is like saying the
>gifts of nature like Basmati/neem belongs to america,
>it does not belong to anybody!! It belongs to nature!!
>The concept of having a visual representation is GUI
>and it cannot belong to people of Microsoft just bocs
>they did a wonderful GUI. They might have contributed
>but not own it.


You know what? Frankly , I think Windows GUI su**s when compared to
Apple's. However, I think it is better than what Gnome or KDE currently
has to offer. I was talking about the lack of a 'usability' culture in a
lot of OSS products.I'm a big usability/HCI buff...so trust me, I find
Windows bad on this front quite often too. Trust me, if Gnome or Kde
work together with people like Jacob Nielsen (www.useit.com) or Bruce
Toggazzini (www.asktog.com), you'll be giving Bill Gates sleepless
nights :-)

Having said that, I'll be surprised if someone tells me that KDE or
Gnome totally ignored Windows when they developed their GUI. If you look
at the history of GUI, Windows is quite different from Mac (common menu
bar). I find Gnome /KDE (and do I need to start on Lindows) eerily
similar to Windows...especially stuff like the taskbar, start button
which is very much MS specific. If this is a coincidence, fine. But I
really doubt it. However, the Gnome /KDE guys have innovated on MS
GUI...well..for that atleast, kudos to them. However, what's the shame
in admitting where you got your inspiration from? Don't be like Deva or
Anu Malik....:-)

>You argument favoring MS seems to come more out of
>fascination than facts!! You might have to dump ur
processor/monitor/graphics card in the not-so-distant future, I sure
presume u will do >that to see the "Long-Horn". No counter-plan for OSS,
just design a much more friendlier GUI, constant improvisation -as we
call it!!

Very true...I find MS fascinating. But unfortunately, this thread never
gave me the chance to talk about other companies of which I'm a bigger
fan , namely, Google and Apple.However, I've tried to back up my
arguments with facts whenever possible...unfortunately, when we get into
philosophical debates, it isn't possible for me to link to
surveys/stats, is it?

As for Longhorn, yes, I wouldn't mind upgrading my comp. I'm sure my
current comp would be in a unusable state by then. I'm sure very few of
you would be using the same config three years from now as you're using
today.

Regarding IBM and Sun (sorry, couldn't find something small enough to
quote)
------------------------------------------------------------------------
--

With IBM and Sun, I agree with Eric. S. Raymond when he says Sun needs
to make Java open-source. You can't pay lip service to a set of
principles and happily ditch it when it suits you. For example, the
members of this group have been prepared to defend OSS very passionately
just as I've tried to defend the 'other side'. However, I really don't
agree with people supporting one side when it suits them and then
happily forgetting about OSS when it comes to their cash cows.

I say make Java open source. Make it a project on SourceForge. Stick it
to MS and .NET :-) Then , we can all have fun.


Regarding Intel and AMD
----------------------------------------

The principles of GNU extend beyond software . I remember reading of
some Open Hardware projects recently but I can't find the link on
slashdot. Anyway, the point I was trying to make is...by your argument,
Microsoft doesn't trust its customers with the secrets behind Windows.
Ok...point taken. Then, why don't you say Intel doesn't trust its
customers with its processor technology? I'm sure AMD would like to look
at how hyper-threading works. Maybe one of us can improve it. How does
this argument relate only to Microsoft? All I'm saying here is...don't
blame Microsoft alone of something. There are a lot of companies who
believe in the same stuff as MS does but doesn't talk about it openly.

>They have been doing it for decades together!! What is
>that going to result in? 
>The most-perfect-creation-of-mankind-the-magnum-opus
>called Longhorn?? We`ll see that!!

Hmmm..the first Windows OS came out in 95. Error reporting came only 2
years ago. So I don't see the 'decades' timeline. As for the results,
they're coming in the form of service packs and upgrades. Do look at
what's coming in XP SP2.Longhorn is over 3-4 years away.



>Anyway I have a question to ask, is ur Windows
>XP bought, or just simply 'loaded and installed'? Have
>u bought ur Windows XP CD from a "Windows certified
>vendor" or just one of ur friend`c CD like almost all others(including
me) and most of them who open this mail in their "Windows".If u say >u
bought it for 6000 odd rupees...:)) haha. I`ll be waiting for a honest
answer from you!!


I was waiting for this question :-). Anyway, let me say that atleast for
the last 3 years, I've been running genuine copies. The truth is, I get
Windows from 2 places. One is from my college which has a MSDN Academic
subscription which lets students install software at home(which means I
have legal copies of Visual Studio.NET,Office,etc). Another one is the
copy I've got from Microsoft for my Student Ambassador-ship.

>The OSS world - yes. The programming world - no.

Sorry, my mistake here. What I meant was 'OSS World - yes. Non-OSS world
- no). I was basically trying to make the point that in the non-OSS
world, people don't feel that they need access to source code. Now, I'm
saying this is what they 'feel' . Feel free to flame me on whether
they're right :-)

>But what r u trying to tell
>me, there arent anybody involved in 'paid' OSS work.

Absolutely not. But are you sure that there are more job opportunities
with developing OSS than 'proprietary' software? If you say 'yes', then
you're sadly mistaken, my friend.I'm saying that compared to
closed-source, OSS has far lesser employment avenues (I'm talking of
hardcore development - not administration,etc). However,a caveat
though...I find it interesting that no one replied to my open question
on whether they make money by developing OSS software. I'm very curious
to know of possible employment avenues through OSS...so I'll be really
happy if some professionals on the group could tell us about the cool
OSS work they do . (I'm being sincere here...after all, I'm a geek too
:-) )

>What do u mean 'expose'?

When I say 'expose', I mean taking the risk of people copying your code
and making money of it with you ending up with nothing. As you say,
developers might need it. But how do you protect yourself from
plagiarism(I'm not sure what the correct term is when it comes to
software).? Is copyleft good enough?

Ok..one small request. I've been trying to Google and see incidents
where the GPL has been brought up legally. Does anyone know of any
incidents where the GPL /copyleft has been brought to a court of law
other than with SCO? 


>What if OSS followed MS there in MIT?? You wud have
>said OSS guys r trying to counter MS with their
>"shameless rippings"(as u wud call them). I`m sure u
>wud have.......

Come on...you can't guess at what I would have said. And, please, like
I've already stated, MS at MIT was due to the students of MIT.If the
students want MS there, why deny them?


>>That`s bcos ur busy restarting MS!! :-)

Fine ...fine. I'm trying to think of something funny to say regarding
recompiling your kernel to get sound from your computer.....but anyway,
I'll stop myself :-)

>If it`s wrong information that Ms is spreading it`s
>word on seeing somebody else spread their 'gospel'
>then the point can be accepted. As again, it wud have
>been seen the other way around!!

I'm happy to see that you're actually admitting that there was wrong
information in the first place. However, it is not possible to
contemplate the 'would-have-beens'. I'm not saying that it is totally
out of the question...If the roles were reversed,I'm sure there are
clueless people on my group who would say that LUG is following
MS....but I guess they exist everywhere , don't they? (And no jokes
about me being one of those clueless people :-) )

>Alas ur coming in terms with OSS!! Welcome to the
>club, my dear friend!!

Signs of me spending way too much time on this group. I'm probably going
to do badly in my sem labs today because of these mails...I think I'll
blame OSS. OSS is evil...look...it made me flunk my exams ;-) I wonder
whether my examiners would take kindly to the idea of the other students
in the exam hall 'sharing' their knowledge. ;-)

<disclaimer> Ok..that was a joke. A very bad joke..but a feeble attempt
at one nonetheless</disclaimer>


Ok...this has gone on long enough. Let me try and summarize as
Sudharshan has asked me to.



First of all, I've not been clear as to MS's attitude with Open source.
Let me try and explain. 

When you guys say 'Open Source' , you mean the GPL. However, when MS
says open-source , they mean anything but the GPL. Basically, its like
this. MS believes in releasing parts of their code to selected people if
they believe that the act would be mutually beneficial. Some times, they
chose to release it to the public as well. However, MS is very staunchly
against the GPL..especially what they call the 'viral' nature.

However, what they do believe in is that not ALL code should be open
source. MS wants to have a choice as to which code can be made visible
to the public and which code stays secret. This choice doesn't exist in
the OSS world(as that would go against the very tenets of the FSF).

So please do understand, when MS says 'open source', they mean the act
of releasing source code and giving you the ability to do anything with
it (without having to make public your changes as well). If you offer
suggestions /improvements, it is upto MS to take it in or not. However,
you're free to make money out of it...and keep your modifications
secret.

I hope I cleared up some of the confusion surrounding MS's principles on
OSS.If you still have any doubts, please do post questions about that
only (MS views on OSS licenses) in a separate thread and I'll try to get
people more informed than me to reply.


Now, like Sudharshan said, I've both said that I use Linux and at the
same time , criticized parts (the GUI,etc). Now, criticizing does not
mean that I don't like Linux. At no point have I actually said that I
don't Linux. My criticisms stem from my views on flaws that exist in the
current-day Linux world(whether they're perceived or real is left to
you). As for my act of criticism, I would like you to read
http://aroundcny.com/technofile/texts/kde_react99.html. I genuinely want
Linux to do well. I don't want to see Microsoft as the only OS vendor.
If they don't have competition, they won't bother innovating (like with
IE). Competition is always good.

Now, as for my suggestions to this group. Well..where do I start? How
about how I got into this group?

Basically, even though I run Linux at home, I'm still very much a Linux
newbie. It took quite some time for me to get familiar with stuff...and
I still struggle with simple things such as installing dependencies to
rpm files. So I thought'Hey...just as my .NET group helps people with
.NET, maybe a Linux group can help me out'. A friend of mine in the
Bangalore LUG had once mentioned this group. After a bit of Googling, I
managed to sign up.

I've been very much a passive observer (I believe the appropriate term
is 'lurking'). And trust me, I've learnt a lot.However, when I saw that
there were some false facts being spouted about my group about the stuff
my friends have been doing in other colleges, I decided to clear up a
few things. Little did I expect that it would spawn off such a monster.

Frankly, I was overwhelmed by the respnse I got. I strongly considered
not replying at all..in my early mails, I had specifically asked whether
people wanted me to stop. However, since people here seemed to enjoy the
discussion(and I've enjoyed it tremendously too), I started replying to
this thread. Pretty soon, I was replying to any thread criticizing
Microsoft or closed-source group. This was probably a mistake and I
should've stuck to this thread alone.But anyway...

 Its not for me or you to decide who's going to win in the long run -
closed or open source. Ultimately ,it's the consumer who'll decide. But,
I want to see a nice fight...I want to see competition for MS. A
monopoly can never be good anywhere. However, what does pain me is the
obsession around MS in the OSS world. Guys, if you're gonna forever
think of MS as the enemy and celebrate whenever they trip up, then
you're wasting your time.

GNU/OSS is an intriguing concept by itself. Yes, I'm not convinced of it
today...maybe someone else will make such a compelling argument one day
that I'll switch over too. But whatever the case, the principles of Free
software are rock-solid and they need no MS-bashing to help them. For
every minute you spend talking about Microsoft trying to brainwash
students here in Chennai...is another minute that MS spends tirelessly
innovating.

Nowehere in all I've read about OSS does it say that closed software and
OSS can't co-exist. We're gonna be using both for a very long time to
come...so might as well get used to it.

My suggestion is this. This is a 'Linux user group'. Not a 'Lets bash
Windows' group or a "M$ s**ks' group. Like I've already said, lets talk
about Linux and other OSS software. Lets talk about GNU ideology. Lets
talk about RMS meeting Kalam. Lets not talk about Microsoft getting
hacked...or Microsoft opening up a group in some Chennai college.Do
understand that not all the people here necessarily agree with the GNU
principles (such as me). However , we do want to try out Linux(the
product)...such constant talk around Microsoft turns us away.

Let me try to answer the 'core question' to the best of my ability.
Microsoft believes that GNU/OSS belittles the concept of IP(Intellectual
Property). You feel that OSS gives you chice...fine...fair enough. MS
believes that GNU takes away the ability to make money and profit from
your work though the GPL says this is not the case. Whether they're
right or wrong is not for you or me to decide...its the consumer who'll
decide .

Anyway, I hope this is the last mail on this thread.I've had immense fun
and learnt a lot. I've made mistakes and have been corrected
appropriately too. However, I'm pained to hear that a lot of people here
don't really find this thread useful (my posts have been called
'constant rubbish and nonsense'. I'm all for open debate...if not here,
I invite you all to sign up in my group at
http://groups.msn.com/cnugstudent

I think both our sides have done our fair share of 'point-proving'. I
only regret the fact that MS had only me to defend
them...unfortunately,I couldn't get more informed people to sign up to
this mailing list in time. So all of you only got to hear my
opinion..while I got to hear a lot of people's opinions. 

Well, this brings us to the end (hopefully). I've to admit I thoroughly
enjoyed myself and I don't regret signing up at all. I unfortunately
missed out on the last LUG meet in IIT but I'm going to make it a point
to attend the next meet.  I would also like to request one of you to do
sessions on Mono/dotGnu for my group's meets. What say? 

In the end, as geeks, such competition between MS and GNU is good as it
means that not only do we get opposing view-points...but we also get
some cool software and technology in the process. And I guess, in the
end, the end-user is the ultimate winner in this battle...as he should
be.

Once again, thanks for such an enlightening discussion. I'm sorry if I
offended anybody...you won't see anymore mails from me unless
specifically asked for.


Regards,
Sriram Krishnan

From RamP at ibsplc.com  Fri Apr  2 04:18:44 2004
From: RamP at ibsplc.com (Ram Prakash)
Date: Fri, 2 Apr 2004 09:48:44 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Are you serious? - Summary
Message-ID: <OFE39B3FBA.05FDC624-ON65256E6A.0015C7E8@ibsplc.com>

What I say:

Hey, I thought up a groovy new algorithm for Process Scheduling. I want to 
implement
it and see it working in real time. How do I do it?
I have choice:
1) Implement in Windows.
2) Implement in Linux.

Choice 1:
Implement in Windows - Er, but, I don't have source code for windows 
kernel to compile.
What do I do? Choice again:
1) Join Microsoft.
2) Join a company which has  been given access to MS Windows Source Code.
3) Get admission into some University which has access to MS Windows 
Source Code.

Now,
Choice 2:
Implement in Linux.
Good - We have all we need. Sit at home. Download source code.
Write my code. Compile. Run. Simple. :)

Now, What they say:

Hey, I have got this groovy neat algorithm for Process Scheduling.
I want to sell it and make money out of it. If I give away the source,
someone else will make money out of it.


I believe that this is the basic difference.

One sees Software as Knowledge.
Other sees Software as Product from an assembly line.

What I feel is we can see Software as Knowledge and still earn money as 
long as
we keep pace and try to be the best in what we dish out. That, I believe, 
is OSS.

Regards,
Ram
--

  | Hey, I have got this groovy neat algorithm for Process Scheduling.
  | I want to sell it and make money out of it. If I give away=20
  | the source,
  | someone else will make money out of it.

actually what you missed out is the fact that, the community as a
whole would make money out of it. the kernel with your schedular
would be used by service providers (and a hell lot of other people),=20
and they would make money. it would be used by the poor farmers of
india to get weather data, and hence improve productivity, and=20
hence make india shine ;) . examples can be plenty.

its like a one rupee coin. its such a little amount, one might thing.
but when it is in circulation, it churns out work, which might go to
thousands .. lakhs .. millions of rupees!!

look at the linux kernel. Business worth *******$ !! has been=20
extablished around it.=20

so the community might not directly use your piece of contribution
and make money, but actually you are helping _generate_ money by=20
supporting FLOSS.=20

at the end, you might just wonder what _you_ would get after all ... ;)
and that's where people find it difficult to digest the FLOSS philo.

saha

> portal for our department of CS at CEG.  PostNuke is being talked about
> security.  From the PHPNuke-howto, it seems like PHPNuke people claim that
> they are not second to PostNuke in anyway.  Did anybody tried them?  Which
> one of them seems to be most appropriate for you?

From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Fri Apr  2 06:08:08 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Fri, 02 Apr 2004 11:38:08 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Closing rants and opening the freedom to learn
Message-ID: <406D0348.1070609@md4.vsnl.net.in>

,----[ Sriram Krishnan <ksriram@gmx.net> ]
| Well, I guess it was only a matter of time before this came up. But
| anyway, let me clarify. I'm NOT an official representative of Microsoft
| by any stretch of the imagination. The reason I became a Microsoft
| Student Ambassador is because I find their technology cool and love
| talking about it. This is no way means that I'm talking for Microsoft.
`----        

You  say that  you blog  at http://www.dotnetjunkies.com/weblog/sriram
There, you have given a link to
http://www.microsoft.com/india/msdn/academia/Ambassadors.aspx  
where your  name, email id, photograph have been included in the list
of Student Ambassadors whose role is :
<quote>
Student Ambassadors are  Microsoft's representatives among the student
community and  the key  contacts for students  working on .NET  or for
those who require assistance from Microsoft.
</quote>

According to  the official  website of MS,  you are  among Microsoft's
representatives,  and  yet you  claim  that  you  are not.   Were  you
ignorant about the  plans of MS for you?  Or, are  you ashamed of your
role?  Your diabolic rants only  waste time and space in the archives.
There is no need to reply  to every meaningless accusation, and may be
it is better to ignore rants for good.

The concern is that the student community should be alert and alive to
the emerging trends, and analyse objectively the benefits derived from
using free  software over non-free software.  Suraj  recently posted a
link  to  http://zeus.polsl.gliwice.pl/~nikodem/linux4chemistry.html .
I  downloaded  garlic and  tried  using  it.   One can  visualise  the
molecular structure  of vitamins,  protiens, and many  other compounds
with great ease  using Garlic, which is a free software.   I am not an
engineer  but  I  do  envy  the resources  available  to  the  student
engineers  of the  day  to  learn and  improve  their knowledge,  made
possible through  the free software  movement.  There are  better ways
students  could use  time available  to  study and  use free  software
programs, and think of using or improving them for the benefit of all.



From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Fri Apr  2 06:07:34 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Fri, 02 Apr 2004 11:37:34 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Fwd:  More Rants
Message-ID: <406D0326.8090708@md4.vsnl.net.in>

------Forwarded Message------
From: Sriram Krishnan <ksriram@gmx.net>
Subject: RE: [Ilugc] Are you serious?
To: "'K. Ramanraj'" <ramanraj@md4.vsnl.net.in>
Date: Fri, 02 Apr 2004 05:24:42 +0530


 >>You are  a Student Ambassador  of Microsoft and an  Official Microsoft
representative, and one  need not expect you to  understand or
 >>support free  software  licenses or  principles,  and  instead,  you
could  be expected to  promote the  profits and business  of
 >>Microsoft  in every possible


Well, I guess it was only a matter of time before this came up. But
anyway, let me clarify. I'm NOT an official representative of Microsoft
by any stretch of the imagination. The reason I became a Microsoft
Student Ambassador is because I find their technology cool and love
talking about it. This is no way means that I'm talking for Microsoft.
In the same way, I do not expect you to talk officially for the FSF.
This is just an informal (and a quite fun)discussion between a bunch of
people who believe in different stuff..and who're trying to get stuff
clarified. So far, I've been happy with the way this discussion has been
conducted vis.a.vis no personal attacks, name-calling,etc.A lot of
people have come forward with their opinions (I admit, quite a few of
which I don't agree with) and it is understandable. The views and
opinions in my mail are very much my own (I'm not sure MS would take
kindly to me saying that the IE team has been sleeping for the last 3
years)

But I would never say that this discussion was bad. You always need open
debate in a free(no pun intended) society.. There can be no 'winner' or
'loser' in this debate. However, the important thing is what we all gain
from the process.

Again, back to my student ambassador thing, my only job is to educate
students about the Microsoft technologies already available. I'm not
here to sell anything...I'm sure I have counterparts evangelizing OSS
among students here in the LUG as well. If any of you want to talk to me
in person and figure out ways of working together, you are free to mail
me at ksriram@gmx.net


 >>by even writing non-stop  nonsense to a gnu/linux user group. One  can
know  about principles  from  the
 >>licenses  and other  public reports, and misstatements don't help
anybody.

Ok...this I object to. I really don't think I was writing 'non-stop
nonsense'. I've made mistakes on a few occasions and have been aptly
corrected by the members of this group. However, I'm sad that you think
that I'm in some way bringing disorder to this group. So, I've decided
to end the thread 'Are you serious' with a final reply to Sudharshan.

Do read my post to Sudharshan for my final take on the various issues
discussed. Hope you guys had as much fun as I did and learnt as much as
I did. If any of you were offended, once again , I offer my sincerest
apologies.

Regards,
Sriram
 

---------------------------------------------------
 
I blog at http://www.dotnetjunkies.com/weblog/sriram
 
----------------------------------------------------

From Sajith T S <sajithts at myrealbox.com>  Fri Apr  2 07:20:43 2004
From: Sajith T S <sajithts at myrealbox.com> (Sajith T S)
Date: Fri, 02 Apr 2004 12:50:43 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Closing rants and opening the freedom to learn

Ramanraj K wrote:

> According to  the official  website of MS,  you are  among Microsoft's
> representatives,  and  yet you  claim  that  you  are not.   Were  you
> ignorant about the  plans of MS for you?  Or, are  you ashamed of your
> role?  Your diabolic rants only  waste time and space in the archives.

The dialogue here so far have been very civil and open, but I think this
is unfair :-( Sriram's rants has not been diabolic - rather, it gave us
a view of the "other side."

I'm all for free software, I believe the existence of free software and
GNU project has made computing (and the world in general) a much better
place than what it could have been without it. And that is the important
thing. But free software is not perfect, and Sriram does has some valid
points - that he's a Microsoft Student Ambassador doesn't change them at
all. I mean, we should be more concerned abbout improving ourself as a
community.

Sajith.

sigs waste bandwidth.

From suraj at symonds.net  Fri Apr  2 07:33:13 2004
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Thu, 1 Apr 2004 23:33:13 -0800
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Are you serious? - needs summarizing!!
In-Reply-To: <20040401203320.79920.qmail@web60601.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040401203320.79920.qmail@web60601.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20040402073313.GA4409@symonds.net>

Sudharsan S.N. wrote on Thu, Apr 01, 2004 at 09:33:20PM +0100: 
,----
| You argument  favoring MS seems to  come more out  of fascination than
| facts!! You  might have to dump ur  processor/monitor/graphics card in
| the not-so-distant  future, I sure presume  u will do that  to see the
| "Long-Horn".  No  counter-plan  for  OSS,  just  design  a  much  more
| friendlier GUI, constant improvisation -as we call it!!
`----

so  does your  argument. It  stems from  a fascination  about  the OSS
philosophy. The  point of this  entire thread is whether  source being
open  is really  necessary  (and advantageous)  than  a closed  source
system (which  in our example is  Microsoft -- a bad  example since an
operating  system that has  its roots  from DOS/Win3.1  will obviously
have  difficulty scaling to  the modern  day security  / extensibility
requirements). Let me bet that IF GNU was not based on Unix and say it
was based  on some  other fancy  idea, it might  not have  become this
successful.

Let  us  consider,  SAP  for   example.   Its  almost  going  to  beat
GnuEnterprise hands down. The point being, SAP has been in development
for ages.  Its  become perfect over X years  with an N-thousand people
working / giving  feedback / fixing it. Given  the closed source model
SAP uses, its refinement cycle is not faster. But with a free software
/ open  source development cycle,  GNU enterprise will reach  the same
level of 'maturity' in less than X years if N-squared-thousand+ people
work  on it.   (ok, dont  bring in  the million  monkeys jumping  on a
keyboard analogy -- A large fraction of Open Source developers work on
a  said project  because they  are interested  in it  and  they almost
certainly would  know what they  are doing). Take emacs  for instance,
its  older  than   me!   I'm  sure  the  man   hours  that  went  into
writing/refining emacs is *huge*.

The disadvantages I see of the  open source model is when:

a.  the  software  needs  not  just  programming  expertise  but  ALSO
functional knowledge (like SAP for example)
b.  the  software  is   considered  "uncool"  by  the  majority  (like
'accounting packages' for example).

There are over a hundred  different types of audio-player software and
shoot-em-up  types  games.   Why  aren't there  that  many  Enterprise
software or say an Encyclopaedia encarta thats got flashy animations?

The technical stabilitiy /  excellence argument will almost always see
most  proprietary software  as advanced  / better  than  the Free/open
source equivalents simply because lots of man hours have gone into its
making (although, things have changed radically now (especially on the
server side)).

Certainly I do see a lot of  good (good == software gets better. Not a
single individual's pocket) due to Free/Open Source software. 

,----
| "Ignorance is bliss!!" and for the others
`----

Atleast my office  accountant thinks so. :) (especially  after he sees
all of us  running between BSD boxes and  occasionally tripping over a
bunch of cables)

cheers,

  -Suraj

| in the sky because it is 400 times farther away.

From: sudharsan at rediffmail.com (=?iso-8859-1?q?Sudharsan=20S.N.?=)
Date: Fri, 2 Apr 2004 09:46:23 +0100 (BST)
Subject: [Ilugc] appache index.html problem
Message-ID: <20040402084623.33318.qmail@web60609.mail.yahoo.com>

>next i deleted the file index.html from /var/www/html
>and when again connect by

>http://kaavi-server/

>i again get the same page of the index.html ...? but
>when use the ip address

Cud be cached pages!! But anyway check the document
root and NamedVirtualHost directive just above the
last section of the conf file. Try to retype them!!

Cached pages can be deleted by deleting history and
offline content and i u use opera just hit File-->
delete private data.

Restart system+service and try again!! -
S.N.Sudharsan.

Why won't you let this go? Anyway, ad nausem, let me point to the very
first mail I sent to this group where I introduced myself in the very
first paragarph. Or in my latest summary mail to Sudharshan where I
spoke about where I got Windows XP from.I definitely haven't been trying
to hide. It would have been easy for me to hide...just remove my email
sig and post from a different id. In fact, all throughout, I've been
exhorting people to sign up in my group. If you were one among the
people who had taken up my offer, you would have seen me sign mails
there as 'Microsoft Student Ambassador' .I only talk of myself as an
ambassador when I'm doing work for MS (as in going to other colleges and
talking for MS or talking in MS events).

As for the 'official' thing , I meant that I'm not talking for Microsoft
here. They do not edit or influence anything I say. And please stop
trying to make me out as some sort of MS lackey...I'm definitely not.

When I'm fulfilling my role as a student ambassador, I'll be exhorting
students to start learning .NET and get in touch with other students
learning .NET. I'll talk about where you can get access to various
Microsoft technologies. I'll talk about how you can get the resources
you need from MS. Have I done any of this in any of my mails?

Please do realize that I've a brain and I think on my own...just because
I'm involved with Microsoft does not make me a 'diabolical ranter'. If
you have an issue with any specific point I've raised, do reply on that
thread rather than resorting to personal attacks.

Ok...if I go on any longer, I'll definitely be wasting archive space.

>Frankly , I think Windows GUI su**s when compared to

comparing Windows and Linux. You didnt get the point I

wud obviously be similar and not 'copied','pirated' or

C`mon, how many times do u want me to repeat it? Even
if there was some other compnay which wud have started
something called GUI it wud have had these
features.....the concept of GUI is not copyrighted to
Windows...........What do u expect KDE or GNOME to
have...functions/buttons that pop out of the monitor??

>in admitting where you got your inspiration from?

>Anu Malik....:-)

I`ve given over 27 programmes in the All India Radio
and Doordarshan, well I can counter your "musical"
opinion. Deva and Anu malik can compose music taken
from the basic seven notes, that is not copying. Only
if they recycle from boyzone and BSB stuff people call
it piracy!! GUI and music are similar, but u say music
belongs to Boyzone and deva cant` copy it!! Ultimately
music doesnt belong to anybody, they r only the same 7
notes, modified,refined and fine tuned. So is GUI!!
The same iconic representation, user interaction using
input devices,etc,...........

this thread never
>gave me the chance to talk about other companies of
which I'm a bigger
>fan , namely, Google and Apple

that`s innately understood!! It applieas to
Sun/Moon/IBM.................and Mannar & Co. too!!

with it, if it`s good-it`s good. A spade has to be

full time professionals working on SAP, whereas the
OSS 'community' as we call it comprises of a majority
of hardcore hobby programmers....the most known one
being Linus, as to what he was, when he started it!!

>a.  the  software  needs  not  just  programming 
expertise  but  ALSO
>functional knowledge (like SAP for example)

>server side)).

seriously and as I have elucidated above the sheer
extent of "hobby programmers" than "employees". But

now!!

From metallica_tony at yahoo.com  Fri Apr  2 12:47:16 2004
From: metallica_tony at yahoo.com (K.Sriram)
Date: Fri, 2 Apr 2004 04:47:16 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Problem in movie player
In-Reply-To: <20040402121427.39045.qmail@web8301.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20040402124716.89273.qmail@web21101.mail.yahoo.com>

The best way is to download the tar.gz or tar.bz2
mplayer files, extract them and install. While
installing, it will say "I want this package to be
already installed, ERROR" and then it will exit.
Download those packages (compressed tar) and install
them first. For to know more about installation,
configuration and codecs u just look at the README and
INSTALL files given along with mplayer installation
files. 
Remember, for to have the gui support u have to use 
configure --enable-gui while installing.
This is what I did, and Mplayer is playing
fantastically.

From metallica_tony at yahoo.com  Fri Apr  2 13:24:29 2004
From: metallica_tony at yahoo.com (K.Sriram)
Date: Fri, 2 Apr 2004 05:24:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Bug in passwd !
Message-ID: <20040402132429.23080.qmail@web21113.mail.yahoo.com>

It seems that there is a bug in MD5 hashing algorithm.
I found this thing when I was playing with echo
command. When I echoed some randomly typed letters, It
gave the current users decrypted password partly.
Sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn't. Check
whether u get it or not. 

echo '82 43/25 43+65P80P82P73P76P32P70P79P79P76P10P'|
dc

 If it works for anyone u plz reply me atonce.

From praveen at symonds.net  Sat Apr  3 09:37:54 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Sat, 03 Apr 2004 15:07:54 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] kernel enq
In-Reply-To: <20040401113118.57091.qmail@web41703.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040401113118.57091.qmail@web41703.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <406E85F2.3080302@symonds.net>

naveen kumar wrote:

> i have problem wirh lilo ,
> 
> after making new image i modified lilo but i am unable
> to run lilo.conf .
> 
> i run lile this
> $ lilo
>  error message is command not found .

'lilo' should be run as super user (root). If you are root, '/sbin' will 
be in your default path.

Three possibilities for this error are

1. You are not logged in as root.
	Soln: Log in as root and try running 'lilo'.

2. If you logged in as root and still you don't get it, then '/sbin' is 
not in your default path.
	Soln: Run '/sbin/lilo'.
	PS: If this is the case you will not be able to run any programs in 
'/sbin' just by their names (eg: ifconfig). To avoid this add '/sbin' to 
your path ($PATH).

3. If you logged in as root and have '/sbin' in your path, lilo may not 
be installed or not in '/sbin'.
	Soln: Try to locate 'lilo' using 'locate' or 'find' if you are sure 
that lilo is installed (Normally source compiled installations allow you 
to put in the directory you want. If you installed lilo binaries, it 
should be in '/sbin'). OR GRUB is there instead of lilo.

HTH.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Sat Apr  3 10:56:21 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sat, 03 Apr 2004 16:26:21 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Are you joking? [Previously "Are you serious?"]
Message-ID: <406E9855.7000007@md4.vsnl.net.in>

,----[ Sajith T S <sajithts@myrealbox.com> ]
| The dialogue here so far have been very civil and open, but I think this
| is unfair :-( Sriram's rants has not been diabolic - rather, it gave us
| a view of the "other side."
`----

I did not want to reopen this  thread, but for Sajith's sake, I had to
write  this.  Any rant  advocating MS  is diabolic  in this  list when
as per the jargon  dictionary  at:
http://info.astrian.net/jargon/terms/m/Microsoft.html

<quote>
Microsoft: The  new Evil  Empire  (the old  one  was  IBM). The  basic
complaints are,  as formerly with  IBM, that (a) their  system designs
are horrible  botches, (b) we  can't get source  to fix them,  and (c)
they throw their weight around a lot. See also Halloween Documents.
</quote>

Some of the rants are sick:

,----[ a rant somewhere in this thread  ]
| Though MS licensed a lot of GUI concepts (like
| overlapped windows) from Apple and Xerox, stuff like the start button is
| solely a MS innovation. And what do I see today? Both Gnome and KDE
| shamelessly ripping them off...In fact , nowadays, both KDE and Gnome
| look like a skinned version of Windows. Where is the innovation?
`----

Cars  have had start  buttons for  a long  time.  Computers  also have
power start buttons on them and booting software follows after pushing
on the  power start  button.  It  is only logical  to have  a starting
point for software and there is always a main function that starts the
processes  in software.   To say  that `start  button is  solely  a MS
innovation' is a tall claim  and saying that Gnome and KDE shamelessly
ripped them off makes no sense.

The X Server was designed to  be used in a networked environment, with
a client/server model in mind  in 1980's, before MS Windows came.  The
concepts behind  X Server  are original and  not found in  other other
operating systems.   It is  the X Server  concept that  makes possible
several  very  different  desktop  environments  -  like  KDE,  gnome,
failsafe,  fvwm2,  icewm,  mwm,  olwm, twm,  DyDe,  Enlightenment  and
others, with each  environment having their own wide  range of themes.
This  is  an  innovative  idea  that  makes a  lot  of  sense,  giving
flexibility and usability  to support a wide range  of users and uses.
Making imputations  against KDE and Gnome developers  accusing them to
have shamelessly ripped off is to say the least, a diabolic rant.

The final rant could only be called BBDR==Big Boring Diabolic Rant

BBDR Question:

,----[ BBDR on 02-04-2004 ]
| When I'm fulfilling my role as a student ambassador, I'll be exhorting
| students to start learning .NET and get in touch with other students
| learning .NET. I'll talk about where you can get access to various
| Microsoft technologies. I'll talk about how you can get the resources
| you need from MS. Have I done any of this in any of my mails?
`----

BBDR Answer:

,----[ BBDR on 27-03-2004 ]
| Now, I find this topic's timing ironic because my user group has a
| meeting scheduled in MIT on 28th March (tommorrow). We're expecting an
| audience of over 250-300...and we're going to be doing some fun stuff
| with .NET with some famous industry professionals doing the talking. Its
| gonna be at the New Lecture Hall Complex(opposite Admin block)...and you
| are all invited to come and attend. Its totally free...so why don't you
| drop in and get the other side of the story ?
`----

Now, the Big Question:  BBDR raised the Question
[1] To test memory
[2] To test patience
[3] To prove loyalty
[4] To request the BBDR title
Answer:  All the above

BBDR sounds much like a poor copy of the FUD tried elsewhere, and hope
the haunt of BBDR is over and has END

Gopalarathnam V.



	One of the questions that comes up all the time is: How enthusiastic
is our support for UNIX?
	Unix was written on our machines and for our machines many years ago.
Today, much of UNIX being done is done on our machines. Ten percent of
our
VAXs are going for UNIX use.  UNIX is a simple language, easy to
understand,
easy to get started with. It's great for students, great for somewhat
casual
users, and it's great for interchanging programs between different
machines.
And so, because of its popularity in these markets, we support it.  We
have
good UNIX on VAX and good UNIX on PDP-11s.
	It is our belief, however, that serious professional users will run
out of things they can do with UNIX. They'll want a real system and will
end
up doing VMS when they get to be serious about programming.
	With UNIX, if you're looking for something, you can easily and quickly
check that small manual and find out that it's not there.  With VMS, no
matter
what you look for -- it's literally a five-foot shelf of documentation
-- if
you look long enough it's there.  That's the difference -- the beauty of
UNIX
is it's simple; and the beauty of VMS is that it's all there.
		-- Ken Olsen, president of DEC, DECWORLD Vol. 8 No. 5, 1984
[It's been argued that the beauty of UNIX is the same as the beauty of
Ken
Olsen's brain.  Ed.]
