From metallica_tony at yahoo.com  Sat Apr  3 15:18:19 2004
From: metallica_tony at yahoo.com (K.Sriram)
Date: Sat, 3 Apr 2004 07:18:19 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Bug in passwd !
In-Reply-To: <OF3386704B.64702EC6-ON65256E6B.00427C39@ibsplc.com>
Message-ID: <20040403151819.98617.qmail@web21108.mail.yahoo.com>

This is a calculator based on stack concept ( Last in
First out , LIFO ) i.e pushing and popping.also it
employs a parenthesis free logic invented by a polish
mathematician before second world war. 
Here are some examples ...

echo '65p'| dc  --> pushes the value 65 to a stack and
then as it encounters 'p' it pops out the value as an
integer.

echo '65P'| dc  --> pushes 65 and pops out as a
character.
as the character corresponding to 65 is A it is
printed.

echo '+' | dc  ---> says stack is empty. coz when it
encounters + it pops out last two values from stack,
calculates the sum and it pushes the result to stack.
same applies for *,/ etc.

echo '5 5+p' | dc ---> prints 10.
so 
echo '65P80P82P73P76P32P70P79P79P76P10P' | dc
is enough for printing APRIL FOOL. the other things
are redundant just for confusing.

Looks Pretty good :-)



echo '82 43/25 65P80P82P73P76P32P70P79P79P76P10P'|
> > dc

this LUG) but the people of your community view an invitation to come
and see my group (and I had invited you guys to come and do a session as
well) as diabolic and evil? Well, in that case, then you're
right,Mr.Pichai and I was wrong..then there is a difference between our

disagree...fine.We have opposing viewpoints ...fine. What I take as
fact, you may dispute...and vice versa....that's fine too. But I'm not
sure how any of you can justify going after someone solely by virtue of
where he's from rather than by what he says. Personally, after seeing

has become personal.

Sorry for yet another...and hopefully my last Big Boring Diabolic Rant.

From pdavid at ntc.net.np  Sat Apr  3 18:16:23 2004
From: pdavid at ntc.net.np (Prasanna David)
Date: Sun, 04 Apr 2004 00:01:23 +0545
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT?]Licence fees and GDP per capita
Message-ID: <406EFF77.9060508@ntc.net.np>


http://firstmonday.org/issues/issue8_12/ghosh/index.html


Abstract:

Licence fees and GDP per capita: The case for open source in developing 
countries by Rishab Aiyer Ghosh

There is a strong case for free software (also known as open source or 
libre software) being deployed widely in developing countries. As argued 
in this note, the open source development community provides an 
environment of intensive interactive skills development at little 
explicit cost, which is particularly useful for local development of 
skills, especially in economically disadvantaged regions. Further, this 
note argues that the controversy over total costs of ownership (TCO) of 
free vs. proprietary software is not applicable to developing countries 
and other regions with low labour costs, where the TCO advantage lies 
with open source, and the share of licence fees in TCO is much higher 
than in high labour cost countries. The note concludes with a table 
comparing license fees for proprietary software against GDP per capita 
for 176 countries.

From sukrit at lokniketan.org  Mon Apr  5 04:32:07 2004
From: sukrit at lokniketan.org (Sukrit)
Date: Mon, 05 Apr 2004 10:02:07 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] wireless
Message-ID: <1081139527.24555.0.camel@god.box.in>

I was wondering if anyone on the list knew whether or not wireless
setups have been de-licensed. I'm looking to set up a wireless
transmitter in the middle of my city to beam a community living a little
far away access to broadband internet, because touchtel doesn't reach
that far out. I want to find out where or not it is legal. I think it
has been de-licensed for internal community usage, but whether i would
be allowed to do it for this particular purpose is what i would like to
find out.

                                        Sukrit.D.


From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Sun Apr  4 04:38:22 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Sun, 04 Apr 2004 10:08:22 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] [OT] wireless
In-Reply-To: <1081139527.24555.0.camel@god.box.in>
References: <1081139527.24555.0.camel@god.box.in>
Message-ID: <406F913E.2080505@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/5/2004 10:02 AM]  Sukrit :

> I was wondering if anyone on the list knew whether or not wireless
> setups have been de-licensed. I'm looking to set up a wireless
> transmitter in the middle of my city to beam a community living a little
> far away access to broadband internet, because touchtel doesn't reach
> that far out. I want to find out where or not it is legal. I think it
> has been de-licensed for internal community usage, but whether i would
> be allowed to do it for this particular purpose is what i would like to
> find out.

Internal community usage as in "you can get an internet connection in by 
other means, like broadband, leased line or VSAT, and then set up WiFi 
access points inside your community to share the connection"

Setting up transmitters and repeaters in the city would surely mean that 
you are going to run into ISP license issues.

And another thing you really must take into account is that what you 
propose requires line of sight between your tower and the destination.

	srs


From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Sun Apr  4 05:04:20 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sun, 04 Apr 2004 10:34:20 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Are you joking? [Previously "Are you serious?"]
References: <005f01c4199a$2e23c290$5f6841db@sriram>
Message-ID: <406F9754.8010703@md4.vsnl.net.in>

During the course of this thread, many members raised several issues -
RamanP pointed to portions in the  MS license in reply to the `go sue'
approach,  and  many  other  members  raised issues  pointing  to  the
disadvantages in using proprietary software, for which there have been
no replies till date and they remain substantially unanswered.  If the
advocates of  proprietary software have been searching  for answers in
their favour, and failed to find any, then they have already taken the
first right step, by joining this  list and I sincerely wish and bless
them to soon become full fledged  free software users. It is better to
stop cringing and crying in the darkness and seek light. Free software
gives the  freedom to free  the mind.  It  is never too late  to whole
heartedly join  the movement to work towards  better programs, greater
freedom and profits for all :)

From RamP at ibsplc.com  Sun Apr  4 06:30:52 2004

>http://trends.newsforge.com/trends/04/03/31/1755246.shtml?tid=149

Mr. Mohammed Riyaz, is that site you sent really true/credible?
If yes.
That was one of the most frightening things I have read. Frightening
becos it could affect you and me. I feel eerie and spooked when I think
that I might be subject to subliminal messages, all the time. If
Free Software has such *intentional* harmful tactics. How could one 
believe
propreitry ones? And I have lost respect of RMS.
He says, "Free Software is the freedom to express opinion", as a 
justification
of his act. He can express his opinion. But he should not try to influence
free will of individuals. Sending subliminal messages is like hypnotising
or mesmerising you into doing something. Its far more evil than trying to
monopolise the software industry.

I stand for Free Software. But, I hate RMS.
I shall never use emacs.

If you want to know more about the usefulness/harm of subliminal messages
and mental suggestions google for "Alpha Mind Power".

Regards,
Ram

using linux, you mean

and yes, it is not a hoax, though released on april 1

> http://www.forbes.com/technology/newswire/2004/04/01/rtr1320652.html
>> > 
>> > Google says "Gmail" is no joke, but lunar jobs are
>> > Reuters, 04.01.04, 1:36 PM ET
>> > 
>> > 
>> > By Lisa Baertlein
>> > 
>> > SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (Reuters) - It's not like Internet search service
>> > Google can't laugh at itself, but when an April Fool's joke got out of hand
>> > on Thursday, a real business plan was rumored to be a Web hoax -- and that
>> > was no laughing matter.
>> > 
>> > Privately held Google Inc. had Web message boards buzzing on Thursday over
>> > whether a new e-mail product, announced on Wednesday and meant to challenge
>> > Yahoo Inc. (nasdaq: YHOO - news - people) and Microsoft Corp (nasdaq: MSFT -
>> > news - people), was actually an April Fool's joke.
>> > 
>> > Google's announcement was questioned because of the U.S. No. 1 search
>> > service's unconventional sub-heading on a press release and because it also
>> > posted a fictional job listing seeking engineers for a "Google Copernicus
>> > Hosting Environment and Experiment in Search Engineering (GCHEESE)" lunar
>> > outpost.
>> > 
>> > Google's free e-mail service called Gmail, which will offer significantly
>> > more storage than Yahoo or MSN, "is not a hoax," said Jonathan Rosenberg,
>> > Google's vice president of products.
>> > 
>> > Google's unconventional March 31 press release announcing Gmail helped set
>> > Internet message boards alight because the sub-heading read: "Search is
>> > Number Two Online Activity -- Email is Number One: 'Heck, Yeah,' Say Google
>> > Founders."
>> > 
>> > "It is April Fool's Day. We were having fun with this announcement. We are
>> > very serious about Gmail," Rosenberg said in an interview.
>> > 
>> > Still, the Web was buzzing with speculation.
>> > 
>> > "It's going to go down in history as one of the biggest pranks ever pulled,"
>> > wrote one message poster at Slashdot.org, which bills itself as a news
>> > provider for nerds.
>> > 
>> > That view was countered by others who noted the relatively low cost of
>> > storage and Google's registration of Gmail.com.
>> > 
>> > "The real joke was an advertisement for a job opening in 2007 at their lunar
>> > facility," another Slashdot poster wrote.
>> > 
>> > That recruiting ad -- which can be viewed by clicking on the Google.com link
>> > "Want a job that's out of this world?" -- details the benefits of working at
>> > Google's "Googlunaplex" location on the moon.
>> > 
>> > "The notion that we're actually opening a lunar office is consistent with
>> > the spirit of April Fool's Day, and, yes, it is a joke," Rosenberg said of
>> > the ad, posted around midnight Greenwich Mean Time on Thursday.
>> > 
>> > In fact, Google's informational site about Gmail, at www.gmail.com, was up
>> > and running Thursday during a test period with a small group of users.
>> > 
>> > According to Whois.net, an online service for researching domain name
>> > registration, Gmail.com does belong to Google.
>> > 
>> > Copyright 2004, Reuters News Service

Standing  by the  ideology  of  Free Software  is  very nice.   Asking
everyone  to use  the  term  'GNU/Linux' works  against  it.  From  my
experience  I notice that  people tend  to move  away from  using Free
Software  because of  this "perstering".   I learnt  it the  hard way.

Secondly non-free software  isn't as evil as the  illiteracy / poverty
that  exists  in this  country.   so if  ASHA  wants  to use  non-free
software, i think its fine, but well, I'm speaking for myself :)

cheers,

  -Suraj

Well, thats a different thing -- here is the history:

RMS  was  about to  visit  ILUGC  and we  had  to  quickly change  all
occurences of  'linux' to 'GNU/Linux'  fearing the after  effects. (at
that point  I was the web  master of chennailug.org and  I didn't know
much about the GNU project, so  I changed to make sure ILUGC stands on
the safer  side) But  anyway RMS  turned down the  idea of  visiting a
"LUG". so he visited MIT instead.

So ok, you did a quick sed s/linux/Gnu\/Linux/

There's every reason that I can see to just rename the LUG back to its 
correct name - ilugc.  What was sed can now be unsed I guess.

	srs

just have to frame a nice way of narrating it all.

i have configured a squid proxy server  which uses one static ip which was provided by the ISP....we have a iptables configured which controls outward and inward traffic on the this machine.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Apr  5 12:08:47 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon, 05 Apr 2004 17:38:47 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] mail server/proxy server
In-Reply-To: <20040405115708.92353.qmail@web14805.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040405115708.92353.qmail@web14805.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <40714C4F.8010808@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/5/2004 5:27 PM]  vinoo :

> my question is that i want to install a mailserver , but whether to use 
> the same static IP and configure in the same machine or....go one for 
> another machine and configure a mail server with a differnt static IP?? 
> and route all incoming and outgoing traffic for the second IP through 
> the first machine in which the firewall in configured.

If you do install a mailserver and a proxy on the same machine, please 
make absolutely sure that the proxy doesn't pass HTTP CONNECT requests - 
something like

CONNECT localhost:25 HTTP/1.1

could just make it very easy for spammers to proxy smtp commands through 
your proxy server.

	srs

Hi,

More at http://blogs.msdn.com/robmen/category/4625.aspx and 
http://sourceforge.net/projects/wix/

It's released under the IBM Common Public License or CPL The CPL is a 
'copyleft' license, just like the GPL. The main point of difference is 
that the CPL has a software-patent protection clause, which the GPL does 
not.

(However, Eben Moglen has indicated that this may be included in the 
next version of the GPL, which would make it compatible)


raj

_______________________________________________
Fsf-friends mailing list
Fsf-friends@mm.gnu.org.in
http://mm.gnu.org.in/mailman/listinfo/fsf-friends


--Boundary_(ID_gMNyVdVxQWIhIAfa0jxTvg)--

Use the One True Editor (tm) -- FSF Emacs
You can convert between Unix/DOS file encoding using C-x RET f followed
by either dos or unix.  Of course this would work if you haven't
modified the default keybindings in Emacs.

`Lasu' Releases SAG 0.3 -- Freeware Book Takes Paves For New World Order
by staff writers

	...
	The central Superhighway site called ``sunsite.unc.edu''
collapsed in the morning before the release.  News about the release had
been leaked by a German hacker group, Harmonious Hardware Hackers, who
had cracked into the author's computer earlier in the week.  They had
got the release date wrong by one day, and caused dozens of eager fans
to connect to the sunsite computer at the wrong time.  ``No computer can
handle that kind of stress,'' explained the mourning sunsite manager,
Erik Troan.  ``The spinning disks made the whole computer jump, and
finally it crashed through the floor to the basement.''  Luckily,
repairs were swift and the computer was working again the same evening.
``Thank God we were able to buy enough needles and thread and patch it
together without major problems.''  The site has also installed a new
throttle on the network pipe, allowing at most four clients at the same
time, thus making a new crash less likely.  ``The book is now in our
Incoming folder'', says Troan, ``and you're all welcome to come and get
it.''
		-- Lars Wirzenius 
		   [comp.os.linux.announce]

From vivek at indofuji.com  Tue Apr  6 05:15:17 2004
From: vivek at indofuji.com (Viveka Nathan K)
Date: Tue, 6 Apr 2004 10:45:17 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com> (from v27076685@fastmail.fm on Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 10:28:34 +0530)
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <20040406051517.GW1664@vivek>

This is used to copy a Huge data.
In this case, it will take lesser time than normal
copying process.

It tars the files in current folder (.) and
untar it in the /marathi/marathi folder.

On 04/06/2004 10:28:34 AM, T.K.Venu Gopal wrote:

From askgopal at sify.com  Tue Apr  6 05:45:01 2004
From: askgopal at sify.com (Gopalarathnam V.)
Date: Tue, 06 Apr 2004 11:15:01 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <1081230301.19973.6.camel@tdl-b3037.satyam.net.in>

The command is normally used by sysadmins to copy (uproot) an entire
directory tree under the current directory to a different location.

For example, to copy all files (and directories) from /usr/src
to /usr/local/src, you would do:

(cd /usr/src && tar -cf - .) | (cd /usr/local/src && tar -xvpf -)

Commands executed between () parantheses are executed within a sub-shell
(so that they don't change the path for the current shell).

On Mon, 2004-04-05 at 21:58 -0700, T.K.Venu Gopal wrote:
> hello
> what does it mean, just explain
>  
>  tar cBvf - . | ( cd /marathi/marathi && tar xBVf - )
> 
> venugopal

Date: 06 Apr 2004 11:49:00 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <20040406051517.GW1664@vivek>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
 <20040406051517.GW1664@vivek>
Message-ID: <m13c7hzl0r.fsf@www.kongu.edu>

Its not about less time, its about preserving file permissions,
acc/mod times this that. the && ensures that you do not untar the
stuff in the same directory if for some reason the `cd` fails. the -
indicates standard input and "." indicates pwd. the second part is
grouped inside () to make it a single job whose standard input is the
pipe.

Viveka Nathan K <vivek@indofuji.com> writes:

> This is used to copy a Huge data.
> In this case, it will take lesser time than normal
> copying process.
> 
> It tars the files in current folder (.) and
> untar it in the /marathi/marathi folder.
> 
> On 04/06/2004 10:28:34 AM, T.K.Venu Gopal wrote:
> > hello
> > what does it mean, just explain
> > 
> >  tar cBvf - . | ( cd /marathi/marathi && tar xBVf - )
> > 
> > venugopal
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --
> >   T.K.Venu Gopal
> >   v27076685@fastmail.fm
> > 
> > --
> > http://www.fastmail.fm - The professional email service
> > _______________________________________________
> > To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with
> > "unsubscribe <password> address"
> > in the subject or body of the message.
> > http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc
> > 
> > 
> _______________________________________________
> To unsubscribe, email ilugc-request@ae.iitm.ac.in with 
> "unsubscribe <password> address"
> in the subject or body of the message.  
> http://www.ae.iitm.ac.in/mailman/listinfo/ilugc
> 

-- 
Arvind Kalyan (arv) <arvy at kongu dot ac dot in>
i=0141;do{putchar(i);i=i&1?(0x10|i&0xf0)|(i&0xf)<<1:i&4?0:i|4;}while(i);

don't need.but be careful you may stop some critical app.=20

From praveen at symonds.net  Tue Apr  6 06:52:27 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Tue, 06 Apr 2004 12:22:27 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Problem with GNOME!
Message-ID: <407253AB.40104@symonds.net>

I am running Debian GNU/Linux Sarge (22 Mar 04) with GNOME 2.4. My 
motherboard runs on nVidia nForce 2 chipset which has nVidia GeForce 
IGP. To enjoy accelerated graphics, I installed the XFree driver 
provided by nVidia from their website. When I was running Quake III from 
GNOME, it crashed. Since then I have problems with GNOME. GNOME failed 
to start next time. So, I swithced to Failsafe GNOME session and it got 
started. After that even if I go into the normal sessions, the GNOME 2 
window decorations are gone. I am getting the "Crux" window decoration 
(GNOME 1) as default. Even if I try switching between GTK 2 themes, the 
same window decoration (Crux) remains persistent and only the UI look 
and feel changes. What could be wrong? Should I force install GNOME 
components again to recover?

PS: Now, almost all the games are running without crash. Also, the 
system seems to be pretty stable.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen


From suraj at symonds.net  Tue Apr  6 07:02:52 2004
From: suraj at symonds.net (Suraj)
Date: Tue, 6 Apr 2004 00:02:52 -0700
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <1081230301.19973.6.camel@tdl-b3037.satyam.net.in>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com> <1081230301.19973.6.camel@tdl-b3037.satyam.net.in>
Message-ID: <20040406070252.GA19329@symonds.net>

Gopalarathnam V. wrote on Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 11:15:01AM +0530: 
,----
| For  example, to  copy all  files (and  directories) from  /usr/src to
| /usr/local/src, you would do:
| 
| (cd /usr/src && tar -cf - .) | (cd /usr/local/src && tar -xvpf -)
`----

Another thing I love doing is to move a directory and stuff underneath
it onto a remote machine:

tar -czf - . | ssh remote.host '(cd /path/to/destination/ && tar -xzf -)'

useful tip in my mind

cheers,

  -Suraj

| .

Praveen Kumar wrote on Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 12:22:27PM +0530: 
,----
| GNOME, it crashed. Since then I have problems with GNOME. GNOME failed
| to start  next time. So, I  swithced to Failsafe GNOME  session and it
| got started.  After that even  if I go  into the normal  sessions, the
| GNOME 2  window decorations are gone.  I am getting  the "Crux" window

`----

Did  you try  debugging the  problem by  moving your  .gconf, .gconfd,
.gnome* away?

The best thing would be, in  my opinion, to use something lighter than
GNOME. GNOME is  just too complex and fragile  (atleast from the GNOME
1.4  I  used  to   use).  Sawfish  is  my  always-recommended  choice,
especially if you love customising things :)

cheers,

  -Suraj

From askgopal at sify.com  Tue Apr  6 08:02:59 2004
From: askgopal at sify.com (Gopalarathnam V.)
Date: Tue, 06 Apr 2004 13:32:59 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <20040406070252.GA19329@symonds.net>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
 <1081230301.19973.6.camel@tdl-b3037.satyam.net.in>
 <20040406070252.GA19329@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <1081238579.20003.11.camel@tdl-b3037.satyam.net.in>

Nice thing Suraj, but I would simply do:

scp -r . remote.host:/path

Also, unlike the most popular belief tar doesn't restore permissions
unless the -p option is supplied.

On Tue, 2004-04-06 at 00:02 -0700, Suraj wrote:
> Gopalarathnam V. wrote on Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 11:15:01AM +0530: 
> ,----
> | For  example, to  copy all  files (and  directories) from  /usr/src to
> | /usr/local/src, you would do:
> | 
> | (cd /usr/src && tar -cf - .) | (cd /usr/local/src && tar -xvpf -)
> `----
> 
> Another thing I love doing is to move a directory and stuff underneath
> it onto a remote machine:
> 
> tar -czf - . | ssh remote.host '(cd /path/to/destination/ && tar -xzf -)'
> 
> useful tip in my mind
> 
> cheers,
> 
>   -Suraj
> 
> -- 
> ,-----------------[http://www.symonds.net/~suraj/]---o
> | World War I broke out on August 4, 1914, after Archduke Franz Ferdinand, heir
> | to the Austro-Hungarian throne, was assassinated by a Serbian on June 28, 1914
> | .
> `------------------------------[suraj@symonds.net]---o

Gopalarathnam V.

From: arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in (Arvind Narayanan)
Date: Tue, 6 Apr 2004 14:27:34 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] couldn't believe this!!!!!
In-Reply-To: <7FA74F140B180D478F3E5942BDFBADAC28693A@chnmsg02.gavsin.com>; from anand.kumar@gavsin.com on Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 01:24:20PM +0530
References: <7FA74F140B180D478F3E5942BDFBADAC28693A@chnmsg02.gavsin.com>
Message-ID: <20040406142734.A16640@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>

On Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 01:24:20PM +0530, Anand Kumar Saha wrote:
> hi,
> 
> i was watching the cricket match and in between
> the overs, saw an IBM ad .. on LINUX !! this is 
> the first ad i have ever seen on LINUX on TV. 
> and it had a very _geeky_ appearence.
> 
> it showed a small child. He went east, then west 
> then south and then north and .. well you should
> see the ad urself.
The ad debuted about 6 months ago. Its available online.
In India I think its been running for maybe a month. It
features Mohammed Ali and other stars.
http://www.adage.com/news.cms?newsId=38634
http://www.newsforge.com/business/03/09/08/1210233.shtml?tid=2&tid=33
http://www-306.ibm.com/e-business/doc/content/ondemand/tvspots_linux.html
http://rxns-rbn-sea01.rbn.com/ibmpdc/pdc/open/qtdemand/aug03/prodigy90_med.mpg (8 megs)

Its not the only one. There is an LG MyPC ad in which
a kid is using mozilla on linux.

Transcript of IBM ad:

Open on young boy sitting in chair, camera pans overhead.

Male Voice: I think you should see this.

Female Voice: It's just a kid.

Cut to young boy sitting in front of rock musician.

Rock Guy: This is a G cord. (Strums his guitar)

Cut to boy sitting in chair, side view (overhead).

Male Voice: He's learning. Absorbing. He's getting smarter every day.

Cut to boy with anthropologist sitting across from him.

Anthropologist: Homo habilis was the first to use tools.

Cut to Coach John R. Wooden speaking to boy.

Coach Wooden: A player who makes a team great is more valuable than a great player. Losing yourself in the group, for the good of the group, that's teamwork.

Cut to close-up of boy.

Male Voice: It's happening fast.

Cut to astrologer speaking to boy.

Astrologer: We've always watched the stars. If you look at the sky, you can see the beginning of time.

Cut to soccer player bouncing ball on knee in front of boy.

Cut to Professor Gates speaking to boy.

Mr. Gates: Collecting data is only the first step toward wisdom. But sharing data is the first step toward community.

Cut to side shot of poet speaking to boy.

Poet: Poetry. There's not much glory in poetry, only achievement.

Cut to overhead shot of boy.

Voice: Knowledge amplification. What he learns, we all learn. What he knows, we all benefit from.

Cut to side shot of Sylvia Nasar speaking to boy.

Ms. Nasar: One little thing can solve an incredibly complex problem.

Cut to frontal shot of Penny Marshall speaking to boy.

Ms. Marshall: Everything's about timing kid.

Cut to side shot of businessman speaking to boy.

CEO: This is business. Faster. Better. Cheaper. Constant improvement.

Cut to camera panning overhead, then to Pilot speaking to boy.

Pilot: So, you wanna fly, huh? Wind speed, thrust, it's physics.

Latin Teacher: Res publica non dominetur.

Cut to plumber speaking to boy.

Plumber: Plumbing, it's all about the tools.

Cut to Muhammad Ali.

Ali: Speak your mind. Don't back down.

Cut to camera panning over boy's head into white.

Female Voice: Does he have a name?

Male Voice: His name is Linux.

Arvind
-- 
Q: Do you ever think about quantum computing?  
Linus: I think that's a load of bull.
(From a Linux Lunacy cruise interview. After the presumptuous disparagement
of QC, Linus goes on to confuse it with DNA computing.)

Subject: [Ilugc] about tar

On Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 11:49:00AM +0530, Arvind Kalyan wrote:
> Its not about less time, its about preserving file permissions,
If there are a lot of small files, then it would save time as well.
Copying each file would have a significant latency if one of the
directories were mounted over a network.

Arvind
> acc/mod times this that. the && ensures that you do not untar the
> stuff in the same directory if for some reason the `cd` fails. the -
> indicates standard input and "." indicates pwd. the second part is
> grouped inside () to make it a single job whose standard input is the
> pipe.
> 
> Viveka Nathan K <vivek@indofuji.com> writes:
> 
> > This is used to copy a Huge data.
> > In this case, it will take lesser time than normal
> > copying process.
> > 
> > It tars the files in current folder (.) and
> > untar it in the /marathi/marathi folder.
> > 
> > On 04/06/2004 10:28:34 AM, T.K.Venu Gopal wrote:
-- 
Q: Do you ever think about quantum computing?

of QC, Linus goes on to confuse it with DNA computing.)

From arvy at kongu.ac.in  Tue Apr  6 11:09:51 2004
From: arvy at kongu.ac.in (Arvind Kalyan)
Date: 06 Apr 2004 16:39:51 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <20040406144349.A16897@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
 <20040406051517.GW1664@vivek> <m13c7hzl0r.fsf@www.kongu.edu>
 <20040406144349.A16897@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>
Message-ID: <m1oeq51hxc.fsf@www.kongu.edu>

Arvind Narayanan <arvindn@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in> writes:

> On Tue, Apr 06, 2004 at 11:49:00AM +0530, Arvind Kalyan wrote:

> > Its not about less time, its about preserving file permissions,
> If there are a lot of small files, then it would save time as well.
> Copying each file would have a significant latency if one of the
> directories were mounted over a network.

the tar writes directly to stdout, not to a file. So the saving time
is not possible. You can see the glitches when the files are off-site,
only when you tar to a local file the time saving is achieved by
transfering the tarred file.

> 
> 
> Arvind

[...]


-- 
Arvind Kalyan (arv) <arvy at kongu dot ac dot in>

From red at srasys.co.in  Tue Apr  6 11:28:38 2004
From: red at srasys.co.in (M S Vijaykumar)
Date: Tue, 6 Apr 2004 16:58:38 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] insmod in kernel 2.6?
Message-ID: <20040406112933.6E7AF46C14@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>

#include <linux/kernel.h>
#include <linux/module.h>
#include <linux/init.h>


static int __init myinit(void){
	printk("<1>Hello kernel!");
	return 0;
}

static void __exit mycleanup(void){
	printk("<1>Hello cleanup!");
}

module_init(myinit);
module_exit(mycleanup);


this is the program i compiled using...

gcc -O2 -c -DMODULE -D__KERNEL__ -I/usr/src/linux-2.6/include hellok.c

all is well till this place!

now when i do an insmod ...

$ insmod hellok.o

i get an error saying

"cannot insert module"

whats wrong? i have no clue, could anyone help?

-- 


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From arun at ppeindia.com  Tue Apr  6 12:56:11 2004
From: arun at ppeindia.com (V.Arun (PPE))
Date: Tue, 06 Apr 2004 18:26:11 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] about tar
In-Reply-To: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
References: <1081227514.8068.183961460@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <1081256171.9322.1.camel@ppe>

Hi,

The '&&' in the command is a very useful feature.
It is used in the following format...
command1 && command2 && command3 && ....
In the above example, command2 is executed if and only if
command1 is executed successfully. command3 is executed
if and only if command2 is executed successfully.
This feature is really useful while writing shell scripts.

Arun

Why? What do you think they will do to linux? Make it proprietary?
Control it? Buy it out? 

They can't do any of these things. The code is out there, its free.
No one can control it. The GPL ensures that. There's nothing to 
wait and see.

Obviously IBM's motive is monetary profit. No one thinks they're doing
this out of philosophical conviction. But nothing they can do can
harm linux. And so far, whatever they have done has greatly helped
it.

This kind of anti-corporate paranoia/zealotry helps no one. Please
desist.

May I remind you that IBM spent a billion dollars on linux in 1999?
Yes, billion. And that it employs > 100 kernel hackers? Dozens in
India. And of course hundreds more in linux-related jobs. I think 
many people on this list were wondering how one makes money from
Free Software. Well, this is how. Please don't bite the hand that
feeds you.

Thank you.
Arvind

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Apr  7 02:33:09 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Wed, 07 Apr 2004 08:03:09 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Is Exporting .pst into Evolution possible ?
In-Reply-To: <40735CD7.2030405@md4.vsnl.net.in>
References: <40735CD7.2030405@md4.vsnl.net.in>
Message-ID: <40736865.9080809@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/7/2004 7:13 AM]  Ramanraj K :

> "Is there any utility which can make my MS Outlook XP data file (.pst) work
> in Linux environment? I have Red Hat Linux 9 running and need to export my
> .pst into Evolution of RH Linux 9."

You can convert the pst to an mbox file and then import that mbox into 
evolution.

Plenty of converters available online, or easiest way would be to import 
outlook mail into eudora (which stores mail as mbox) and then open that 
in Evolution.

	srs

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Wed Apr  7 06:03:50 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

Subject: [Ilugc] unsolicited mail -- product sale..
In-Reply-To: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINCECJCPAA.rajendran@xerago.com>
References: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINCECJCPAA.rajendran@xerago.com>
Message-ID: <407399C6.6040001@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/7/2004 11:05 AM]  rajendran :
> I got unsolicited mail today, about (closed)software sales at a website
> called ratedoem.
> http://ratedoem.info  is the URL.
> 
> Just wanted to know if you guys have ever been to the site, whether what the
> site does is above-board and legal...
> 
> And, interestingly, they say, a product, for example, MS Windows XP 2002 is
> 271 dollars (shelfprice) and not 40 dollars (their price) only because of
> the promised tech-support, the beautiful box package, and the printed
> manuals. Could that be true?

It is called OEM software - software that is distributed with something 
else (like when you buy a motherboard, or a new PC etc)

Redistribution of that sort of thing is not always legal - if it was 
microsoft software being advertised in spam, fw it to piracy@microsoft.com

	srs

From bharathi at lantana.tenet.res.in  Wed Apr  7 06:10:30 2004
From: bharathi at lantana.tenet.res.in (Bharathi S)
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 11:40:30 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Next Meet Agenda
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404061855390.28296-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in>

Agenda for Next ILUGC Meeting :-
=============================

Time    : Sat Apr 10 15:00 IST 2004
Venue   : ADI-TeNeT Seminar Hall, 
          CSD 320, ESB, IIT-Madras.

Talk 1  :
=========

Topic   : Network Scanning - Intro
Speaker : Mr. Phani Kumar, DONLab, IIT-M.

Abstract:

Network Scanning is the primary security auditing process used to
prevent the Reconnaissance attacks and measure the online risk. It
involves determining exposures in terms of hosts, OS and services and
further conducting detailed analysis of network activity to uncover
and isolate the threats. Network security scanning involves the
following exploring activities using various techniques:

o PING SCANNING
o PORT SCANNING
o OS DETECTION
o FIREWALKING

The techniques used to perform these four operations are based on the
specifications of the protocols like ICMP, TCP, IP, UDP, FTP etc.


Talk 2 :
========

Topic   : SubVersion
Speaker : Venki and CollabNet Team

Abstract:

A Version control system that is a compelling replacement for CVS in 
OSS. Link: http://subversion.tigris.org/

>From that you can find howto reach the Cell F-15 ( ESB).

From praveen at symonds.net  Wed Apr  7 08:32:37 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Wed, 07 Apr 2004 14:02:37 +0530
Subject: OS Detection [Was Re: [Ilugc] (no subject)]
In-Reply-To: <1081325754.26201.184037353@webmail.messagingengine.com>
References: <1081325754.26201.184037353@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <4073BCA5.80104@symonds.net>

T.K.Venu Gopal wrote:

> how can i say is the system is unix/windows box 
> by ipaddress in a network

By just looking at the IP address, you can't say whether that box is 
Windows or Linux or whatever. But doing a portscan can reveal it. For 
instance, you can use nmap with OS detect switch (-O). This is usually 
done by TCP/IP fingerprinting. This will work out for major OSs.

A portscan of my PC (Runs Windows 2000) gave...

# nmap -sS -PT -PI -O -T 3 praveenk.xxx.xxxxxxx.com
Starting nmap V. 3.00 ( www.insecure.org/nmap )
Interesting ports on praveenk.xxx.xxxxxxx.com (10.1.152.33):
(The 1594 ports scanned but not shown below are in state: closed)
Port       State       Service
21/tcp     open        ftp
80/tcp     open        http
135/tcp    open        loc-srv
139/tcp    open        netbios-ssn
445/tcp    open        microsoft-ds
2401/tcp   open        cvspserver
6000/tcp   open        X11
Remote operating system guess: Windows Millennium Edition (Me), Win 
2000, or WinXP
Nmap run completed -- 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 17 seconds

HTH.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

From a_venkatesh79 at yahoo.co.uk  Wed Apr  7 09:03:55 2004
From: a_venkatesh79 at yahoo.co.uk (venkatesh)
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 14:33:55 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] SSL CA root /Apache
In-Reply-To: <20040407070056.54458.qmail@web14805.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040407070056.54458.qmail@web14805.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20040407085612.C985246BD5@www.ae.iitm.ac.in>

Hi,

Certificates generated using openssl are x.509 standard complaint. So it 
doesn't matter in which platform, you are going to use that. Using openssl 
'ca' cmd, you can setup your own root CA certificate.

If you using windows, You can also get OpenSSL binary for windows from this 
url.

http://www.openssl.org/related/binaries.html

HTH,
venki.

From praveen at symonds.net  Wed Apr  7 12:25:32 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Wed, 07 Apr 2004 17:55:32 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Regarding Mail Server
In-Reply-To: <20040407104154.8BD0823AB1@ws5-3.us4.outblaze.com>
References: <20040407104154.8BD0823AB1@ws5-3.us4.outblaze.com>
Message-ID: <4073F33C.9020203@symonds.net>

Pradheep Kumar wrote:

> How to create a account in mail server. If i am in root how to get inside the mail account (by what command)? I want to create a  mail account for 10 members. just tell me the way and command to get inside.

When you run conventional mail servers (without virtual hosting), then 
adding normal UNIX users will create a mail account for them. For 
instance, if your server is bar.com and you add an UNIX user named 
'foo', then his e-mail id is foo@bar.com (Should have an MX entry in the 
DNS server). If you are using virtual hosting, you are most likely 
running ensim (widely used). If so, goto the ensim control panel and 
create users.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

From tuxkumar at yahoo.com  Wed Apr  7 15:10:03 2004
From: tuxkumar at yahoo.com (SaravanaKumar)
Date: Wed, 07 Apr 2004 20:40:03 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: mv NewMail mbox ??
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404071433410.16788-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404071433410.16788-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in>
Message-ID: <c515km$1dm$1@sea.gmane.org>


Bharathi S wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> How to manually move the new mails from /var/spool/mail/$USER to
> $USER's mbox ?
> 
> Bye :)

cat /var/spool/mail/$USER >> $USER/mbox
echo ""> /var/spool/mail/$USER

BTW, why do u want to do it. Any new mail is stored in /var/spool/mail 
and all read mails moved to $USER's mbox. Any spceific reason for it?


HTH

SK

From mssnlayam at myrealbox.com  Wed Apr  7 17:00:08 2004
From: mssnlayam at myrealbox.com (Suriya Narayanan M S)
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 12:00:08 -0500
Subject: [Ilugc] (OT) - website creation.
In-Reply-To: <1081355694.23930.184063531@webmail.messagingengine.com>
References: <1081355694.23930.184063531@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <20040407170008.GA30736@cs.utexas.edu>

On Wed, Apr 07, 2004 at 10:04:54PM +0530, Mohammed Riyaz wrote:
> Hi,
>  Basic doubt. if i need riyaz.com.. i check if the domain name is
>  available and then when i register the domain, who allocates the IP for
>  my domain?

No one allocates IP for your domain. You just own your domainname. You
go to some webhosting service provider (or your home) and host your
domain there.

> 
> Now if i have uploaded the webpages to a server somewhere, and
> considering i want to run a webserver from my house for a change, now can
> i run registered domain from my house directly.
> 
> what i am trying to ask is how does this IP thing work in this case. if
> ip is allocated to the system where the domain can be found , then do u
> have to register for a new ip when u change the location of the website?

You own the domain. You would have registered your domain with someone
like namecheap.com or verisign, etc. You can tell them which DNS server
handles your domain. So you have to set up a DNS server which maps the
domain name to IP.

> 
> I know my questions arent very clear but i could figure out a better way
> to put it. morever i do not know exact meaning & usage of the word
> 'domain', so bear with it C:
> 
> Mail me off list, since it's off topic.
> 
> Thnaks
> -riyaz
> C:
>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Suresh Ramasubramanian" <linux@frodo.hserus.net>
To: "Ramanraj K" <ramanraj@md4.vsnl.net.in>
Cc: "Chennai LUG" <ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in>; <searchlight@sancharnet.in>
Sent: Wednesday, April 07, 2004 8:03 AM
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Is Exporting .pst into Evolution possible ?


> [4/7/2004 7:13 AM]  Ramanraj K :
>
> > "Is there any utility which can make my MS Outlook XP data file (.pst)
work
> > in Linux environment? I have Red Hat Linux 9 running and need to export
my
> > .pst into Evolution of RH Linux 9."
>
> You can convert the pst to an mbox file and then import that mbox into
> evolution.
>
> Plenty of converters available online, or easiest way would be to import
> outlook mail into eudora (which stores mail as mbox) and then open that
> in Evolution.
>
> srs

> `Lasu' Releases SAG 0.3 -- Freeware Book Takes Paves For New World Order
> by staff writers
>
> ...
> The central Superhighway site called ``sunsite.unc.edu''
> collapsed in the morning before the release.  News about the release had
> been leaked by a German hacker group, Harmonious Hardware Hackers, who
> had cracked into the author's computer earlier in the week.  They had
> got the release date wrong by one day, and caused dozens of eager fans
> to connect to the sunsite computer at the wrong time.  ``No computer can
> handle that kind of stress,'' explained the mourning sunsite manager,
> Erik Troan.  ``The spinning disks made the whole computer jump, and
> finally it crashed through the floor to the basement.''  Luckily,
> repairs were swift and the computer was working again the same evening.
> ``Thank God we were able to buy enough needles and thread and patch it
> together without major problems.''  The site has also installed a new
> throttle on the network pipe, allowing at most four clients at the same
> time, thus making a new crash less likely.  ``The book is now in our
> Incoming folder'', says Troan, ``and you're all welcome to come and get
> it.''
> -- Lars Wirzenius
>    [comp.os.linux.announce]
>

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Apr  8 02:33:56 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 08:03:56 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] (OT) - website creation.
In-Reply-To: <1081355694.23930.184063531@webmail.messagingengine.com>
References: <1081355694.23930.184063531@webmail.messagingengine.com>
Message-ID: <20040408023356.GB129@frodo.hserus.net>

On Wed, Apr 07, 2004 at 10:04:54PM +0530, Mohammed Riyaz wrote:
>  Basic doubt. if i need riyaz.com.. i check if the domain name is
>  available and then when i register the domain, who allocates the IP for
>  my domain?

you go to any webhosting provider (say http://www.pair.com) and get hosting
from them - hey provide you with IP and dns records.

> Now if i have uploaded the webpages to a server somewhere, and
> considering i want to run a webserver from my house for a change, now can
> i run registered domain from my house directly.

set up free dns at http://www.granitecanyon.com and then if you have a static
ip at your house, point the domain to that static IP.

if you have a dynamic ip or a slow link it might be better for you to just
get it hosted at a webhost.

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

mv: cannot move `linux' to `Gnu/Linux': No such file or directory

From rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu  Wed Apr  7 15:49:42 2004
From: rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu (Sridhar R)
Date: Wed, 7 Apr 2004 21:19:42 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Notification of httpd responses asyncronously
Message-ID: <39810.203.197.138.167.1081352982.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>

I am workinig on a client/server project.  Now I have planned to write a
corresponding webclient.  In my system, when a client requests, the server
won't reply back immediately (except for ack), instead it will notify the
client sometime back..  and for this the client will run another server,
that will get the server responses.
The problem comes when I tried to think this in terms of webclient.  How
is this ("event-notification") possible from client browser. (Oh, no I am
not taking about refreshing the browser window repeatedly).
I remember the interface of Yahoo! briefcase fileuploads.  It displayed a
animated progress bar.  No contest was loading at that time (i.e. the
browser progress bar was idle).  But after sometime (after the file got
uploaded), a new page got loaded (finished uploading).
The restriction is, I shouldn't open/connect to any port other than 80 on
client side (so no socket stuffs in javascript?!).
-- 
R. Sridhar



From babu_jayapaul at yahoo.com  Thu Apr  8 08:33:04 2004
From: babu_jayapaul at yahoo.com (babu jayapaul)
Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 01:33:04 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [Ilugc] samba user  problem
Message-ID: <20040408083304.71547.qmail@web11409.mail.yahoo.com>

Dear Friends

I have configured samba 3.0 as my PDC in Fedora. when
i try to configure the domain in win2k, it ask for a
admin user name and passwd to join the domain, I have
<root> as username and passwd. but showing a error as
follows.

"The following error occurred attempting to join the
domain 'ITDOMAIN1'
     
 Username could not be found"

but i have added the root as samba user using the
following command

 "smbpasswd -a root"

     I can able to open the samba root share using the
same username and passwd in win2k network
neighborhood.

please help me 

thanks in advance.

babu j
# This file Modified by Babu-Jey-Linuz on 23/3/04


#================== Global Settings =================
[global]

# workgroup = NT-Domain-Name or Workgroup-Name
   netbios name = Tuxserver
   workgroup = itdomain1
   
# server string is the equivalent of the NT
Description field
   server string = itdomain1

   printcap name = /etc/printcap
   load printers = yes

# this tells Samba to use a separate log file for each
machine
# that connects
   log file = /var/log/samba/%m.log

# Put a capping on the size of the log files (in Kb).
   max log size = 50

  encrypt passwords = yes
  smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd

  unix password sync = Yes
  passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
  passwd chat = *New*UNIX*password* %n\n
*ReType*new*UNIX*password* %n\n
*passwd:*all*authentication*tokens*updated*successfully*

# Most people will find that this option gives better
performance.
# See speed.txt and the manual pages for details
   socket options = TCP_NODELAY SO_RCVBUF=8192
SO_SNDBUF=8192

   addprinter command = /usr/bin/addprinter

   logon drive = H:
   local master = yes
   os level = 65
   domain master = yes 
   preferred master = yes
   domain logons = yes
;   domain admin group = root,administrator
    logon script = logon.bat
   logon home = \\%L\%u\.win_profile\%m

   wins support = yes
   time server = yes
   admin users = root administrator babu
#   domain admin group = root administrator 
   printer admin = @sysadmin
   printing = lprng

# Dynamic Creation of Machine Trust Accounts
  add user script = /usr/sbin/useradd -d /dev/null -g
100 -s /bin/false -M %u


#============ Share Definitions =====================
[homes]
   comment = Home Directories
   browseable = no
   ;writable = yes
   ;valid users = %S
   ;create mode = 0664
   ;directory mode = 0775
   read only = no 
   guest ok = no
   map archive = yes
[cdrom]
   comment = CD Drive
   path = /misc/cd
   valid users = @sysadmin

[software]
   comment = Software's
   path = /mnt/soft
   valid users = @sysadmin

# Un-comment the following and create the netlogon
directory for Domain Logons
 [netlogon]
## Store all samba PDC overhead data in the directory
## /home/netlogon (or whatever you desire)

;   comment = Network Logon Service
   path = /home/netlogon
   browsable = no
;   guest ok = yes
    writable = no
;   share modes = no
;   write list = administrator


# Un-comment the following to provide a specific
roving profile share
# the default is to use the user's home directory
[Profiles]
## Store user profiles in this directory
    path = /home/ntprofile
    browsable = no
;    guest ok = yes
;    read only = No
    writable = yes
    create mask = 0600
    directory mask = 0700
 
# NOTE: If you have a BSD-style print system there is
no need to 
# specifically define each individual printer
[printers]
   comment = All Printers
   path = /var/spool/samba
   browseable = no
# Set public = yes to allow user 'guest account' to
print
   guest ok = no
   writable = no
   printable = yes




__________________________________

Yahoo! Small Business $15K Web Design Giveaway 
http://promotions.yahoo.com/design_giveaway/

# This file Modified by Babu-Jey-Linuz on 23/3/04


#================== Global Settings =================
[global]

# workgroup = NT-Domain-Name or Workgroup-Name
   netbios name = Tuxserver
   workgroup = itdomain1
   
# server string is the equivalent of the NT
Description field
   server string = itdomain1

   printcap name = /etc/printcap
   load printers = yes

# this tells Samba to use a separate log file for each
machine
# that connects
   log file = /var/log/samba/%m.log

# Put a capping on the size of the log files (in Kb).
   max log size = 50

  encrypt passwords = yes
  smb passwd file = /etc/samba/smbpasswd

  unix password sync = Yes
  passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
  passwd chat = *New*UNIX*password* %n\n
*ReType*new*UNIX*password* %n\n
*passwd:*all*authentication*tokens*updated*successfully*

# Most people will find that this option gives better
performance.
# See speed.txt and the manual pages for details
   socket options = TCP_NODELAY SO_RCVBUF=8192
SO_SNDBUF=8192

   addprinter command = /usr/bin/addprinter

   logon drive = H:
   local master = yes
   os level = 65
   domain master = yes 
   preferred master = yes
   domain logons = yes
;   domain admin group = root,administrator
    logon script = logon.bat
   logon home = \\%L\%u\.win_profile\%m

   wins support = yes
   time server = yes
   admin users = root administrator babu
#   domain admin group = root administrator 
   printer admin = @sysadmin
   printing = lprng

# Dynamic Creation of Machine Trust Accounts
  add user script = /usr/sbin/useradd -d /dev/null -g
100 -s /bin/false -M %u


#============ Share Definitions =====================
[homes]
   comment = Home Directories
   browseable = no
   ;writable = yes
   ;valid users = %S
   ;create mode = 0664
   ;directory mode = 0775
   read only = no 
   guest ok = no
   map archive = yes
[cdrom]
   comment = CD Drive
   path = /misc/cd
   valid users = @sysadmin

[software]
   comment = Software's
   path = /mnt/soft
   valid users = @sysadmin

# Un-comment the following and create the netlogon
directory for Domain Logons
 [netlogon]
## Store all samba PDC overhead data in the directory
## /home/netlogon (or whatever you desire)

;   comment = Network Logon Service
   path = /home/netlogon
   browsable = no
;   guest ok = yes
    writable = no
;   share modes = no
;   write list = administrator


# Un-comment the following to provide a specific
roving profile share
# the default is to use the user's home directory
[Profiles]
## Store user profiles in this directory
    path = /home/ntprofile
    browsable = no
;    guest ok = yes
;    read only = No
    writable = yes
    create mask = 0600
    directory mask = 0700
 
# NOTE: If you have a BSD-style print system there is
no need to 
# specifically define each individual printer
[printers]
   comment = All Printers
   path = /var/spool/samba
   browseable = no
# Set public = yes to allow user 'guest account' to
print
   guest ok = no
   writable = no
   printable = yes

> ILUGC website is still hand written. Why don't we go for some content 
> management systems? ILUG Goa and ILUG Bombay are doing this. It's really

Note: A wiki *is* a CMS.

From metallica_tony at yahoo.com  Thu Apr  8 13:27:47 2004
From: metallica_tony at yahoo.com (K.Sriram)
Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 06:27:47 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [Ilugc] Configure Debian
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-DAV8uaK59O5s9p000126f8@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040408132747.95214.qmail@web21111.mail.yahoo.com>

Use
dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86
to reconfigure the server. Before that make sure that
u hav installed all the required packages for X. 
or else open ur /etc/X11/XF86config file and edit it
by hand.

the full server output, not just the last messages.
This can be found in the log file "/var/log/XFree86.0.log".

From praveen at symonds.net  Fri Apr  9 06:52:01 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)

Subject: [Ilugc] Xserver Config
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F65hj59Pa2bZSc00028782@hotmail.com>

Senthil Velan wrote:

I find some reasons for this failure which are explained below.

> 1)  Manage XFree86 4.x server configuration file with debconf?  -  Yes
> 2)  Desired Xserver driver - i810 driver chossed.
> 3)  Identifier of video card - New card
> 4)  Video cards bus identifier - None
> 5)  Amount of memory(in KB) for video memory  -  2048
> 6)  Frame buffer device interface?  - Yes
> 7)  X Key Board rule set  -  xfree86
> 8)  KeyBoard Model  -  pc104
> 9)  Keyboard layout   -  us
> 10)  keyboard variant - none
> 11)  keyboard options  -  none
> 12)  mouse port - /dev/ttyS0
> 13)  mouse driver  - MouseMan
> 14)  emulate 3 button mouse?  No
> 15)  Scroll events?  No
> 16)  Identifier for Monitor - New monitor
> 17)  LCD device  - No
> 18)  Xwindow GUI Characteristics:   Medium  -  800x600 @ 60 hz

What is the model of your monitor? 800x600 @ 60 Hz is pretty low end. 
Your's should be atleast 800x600 @ 60 Hz (If Samtron 45B 14'') or 
1024x768 @ 60 Hz (If Samtron 55E 15''). Try changing this. It should 
definetly work out.

> 19)  Video Mode -  800x600 and 640x480
> 20)  Bit colour = 24 bit

Try going for 16 bit color depth instead.

> 21)  Xserver modules to be loaded  - All modules selected expect the 
> last one.

There is a comment coming behing about the modules.

> 22)  Write files to configuration file?  _ Yes
> 23)  Write default DRI section to configuration file?  - Yes.
> 
> and after putting th command gdm or kdm in the Debian prompt my Monitor 
> blinks for 2 times and XServer shows error:

Some messages striped out.

> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x350" (vrefresh out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x400" (vrefresh out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "720x400" (vrefresh out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (vrefresh out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (vrefresh out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (hsync out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)

See none of your 800x600 is supported because your monitor doesn't 
support it (You informed it that way).

> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1152x864" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x960" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x960" (insufficient memory for 
> mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1792x1344" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1792x1344" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1856x1392" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1856x1392" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1920x1440" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1920x1440" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1400x1050" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1400x1050" (insufficient memory 
> for mode)
> (--) I810(0): Virtual size is 800x600 (pitch 1024)
> (**) I810(0): Default mode "800x600": 40.0 MHz, 37.9 kHz, 60.3 Hz
> (II) I810(0): Modeline "800x600"   40.00  800 840 968 1056  600 601 605 
> 628 +hsync +vsync
> (**) I810(0): Default mode "640x480": 25.2 MHz, 31.5 kHz, 60.0 Hz
> (II) I810(0): Modeline "640x480"   25.20  640 656 752 800  480 490 492 
> 525 -hsync -vsync
> (--) I810(0): Display dimensions: (32, 24) cm
> (--) I810(0): DPI set to (63, 63)
> (II) Loading sub module "fb"
> (II) LoadModule: "fb"

Don't use kernel's framebuffer interface. It sucks in I810. (By defualt, 
the kernel don't have I810 framebuffer, you have to path it instead). 
So, disable 'fb' module.

To sum up, try

1. Set you monitor parameters properly. Better read the monitor manual 
(or it will be displayed on the monitor box) and go for advanced mode to 
be more precise. Or atleast set it to 800x600 @ 70 Hz.

2. Decrease color depth to 16 and give a try.

3. Remove 'fb' module.

Things should be fine then I hope.

PS: Kernel shouldn't be matter at all for this error. Don't change your 
kernel. But kernel 2.4 is always advisible over 2.2. Kernel 2.4 binaries 
are present in Debian 3.0 itself.

HTH.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

From praveen at symonds.net  Fri Apr  9 06:55:12 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Fri, 09 Apr 2004 12:25:12 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Problem with GNOME!
In-Reply-To: <407253AB.40104@symonds.net>
References: <407253AB.40104@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <407648D0.3070207@symonds.net>

Praveen Kumar wrote:

> I am running Debian GNU/Linux Sarge (22 Mar 04) with GNOME 2.4. My 
> motherboard runs on nVidia nForce 2 chipset which has nVidia GeForce 
> IGP. To enjoy accelerated graphics, I installed the XFree driver 
> provided by nVidia from their website. When I was running Quake III from 
> GNOME, it crashed. Since then I have problems with GNOME. GNOME failed 
> to start next time. So, I swithced to Failsafe GNOME session and it got 
> started. After that even if I go into the normal sessions, the GNOME 2 
> window decorations are gone. I am getting the "Crux" window decoration 
> (GNOME 1) as default. Even if I try switching between GTK 2 themes, the 
> same window decoration (Crux) remains persistent and only the UI look 
> and feel changes. What could be wrong? Should I force install GNOME 
> components again to recover?
> 
> PS: Now, almost all the games are running without crash. Also, the 
> system seems to be pretty stable.

I fixed the problem. The broblem was 'sawfish' was starting instead of 
'metacity'. Since 'sawfish' is GNOME 1's I got old window decorations. I 
don't know how it happened. I changed the window manage to metacity by 
editing the session configuration. Now this are pretty fine.

-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

> definetly work out.
>
> > 19)  Video Mode -  800x600 and 640x480
> > 20)  Bit colour = 24 bit
>
> Try going for 16 bit color depth instead.
>
> > 21)  Xserver modules to be loaded  - All modules selected expect the
> > last one.
>
> There is a comment coming behing about the modules.
>
> > 22)  Write files to configuration file?  _ Yes
> > 23)  Write default DRI section to configuration file?  - Yes.
> >
> > and after putting th command gdm or kdm in the Debian prompt my Monitor
> > blinks for 2 times and XServer shows error:
>
> Some messages striped out.
>
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x350" (vrefresh out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x400" (vrefresh out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "720x400" (vrefresh out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (vrefresh out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (vrefresh out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "640x480" (hsync out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "800x600" (hsync out of range)
>
> See none of your 800x600 is supported because your monitor doesn't
> support it (You informed it that way).
>
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1024x768" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1152x864" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x960" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x960" (insufficient memory for
> > mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1280x1024" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1600x1200" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1792x1344" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1792x1344" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1856x1392" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1856x1392" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1920x1440" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1920x1440" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1400x1050" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (II) I810(0): Not using default mode "1400x1050" (insufficient memory
> > for mode)
> > (--) I810(0): Virtual size is 800x600 (pitch 1024)
> > (**) I810(0): Default mode "800x600": 40.0 MHz, 37.9 kHz, 60.3 Hz
> > (II) I810(0): Modeline "800x600"   40.00  800 840 968 1056  600 601 605
> > 628 +hsync +vsync
> > (**) I810(0): Default mode "640x480": 25.2 MHz, 31.5 kHz, 60.0 Hz
> > (II) I810(0): Modeline "640x480"   25.20  640 656 752 800  480 490 492
> > 525 -hsync -vsync
> > (--) I810(0): Display dimensions: (32, 24) cm
> > (--) I810(0): DPI set to (63, 63)
> > (II) Loading sub module "fb"
> > (II) LoadModule: "fb"
>
> Don't use kernel's framebuffer interface. It sucks in I810. (By defualt,
> the kernel don't have I810 framebuffer, you have to path it instead).
> So, disable 'fb' module.
>
> To sum up, try
>
> 1. Set you monitor parameters properly. Better read the monitor manual
> (or it will be displayed on the monitor box) and go for advanced mode to
> be more precise. Or atleast set it to 800x600 @ 70 Hz.
>
> 2. Decrease color depth to 16 and give a try.
>
> 3. Remove 'fb' module.
>
> Things should be fine then I hope.
>
> PS: Kernel shouldn't be matter at all for this error. Don't change your
> kernel. But kernel 2.4 is always advisible over 2.2. Kernel 2.4 binaries
> are present in Debian 3.0 itself.
>
> HTH.
>
> --
> http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen
>

From rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu  Thu Apr  8 17:36:01 2004
From: rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu (Sridhar R)
Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 23:06:01 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] wget recursive retrieval
In-Reply-To: <20040409095330.78577.qmail@web8002.mail.in.yahoo.com>
References: <35379.203.197.138.167.1081444650.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
 <20040409095330.78577.qmail@web8002.mail.in.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <41608.203.197.138.167.1081445761.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>

Raman.P said:
> --- Sridhar R <rsridhar@cs.annauniv.edu> wrote: > I used
>>
>> $ wget -r http://gentoo.org/doc/en/
>>
>> But it started downloading all files starting from www.gentoo.org and
>> the
>> CWD contains the same!
>> I have also searched the wget manual, but '-r' is not behaving as it
>> should.
>> (Am I missing anything?)
>>
>> --
>> R. Sridhar
>>
>
> look at --no-parent option, that should help you.

  So finally I used,

  wget -p -r -np http://gentoo.org/doc/en

  * -p: also download any images,.. linked from the pages downloaded
  * -r: recurse - default depth is 5
  * -np: Download from the directory given, no parent files

  Well, consider this scenario.  I have downloaded files using the default
  depth (5). Now I wish to download from mutually exclusively levels, say
  6-8.  How to do that?
>
> Raman.P
>

From: kksenthilvelan at hotmail.com (K.K.Senthil Velan)
Date: Fri, 9 Apr 2004 16:25:29 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] HSP56 Modem
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV4QG101s7hpJ0002ddfa@hotmail.com>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0033_01C41E4F.45D393C0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I already installed the same Modem (HSP56 Micro) in Redhat 9 =
successfully . So u have to get the source code from the proper web =
site. i don't remember the exact link. But Downloaded the Source code =
and compiled it. Where i faced problem is, I was not able to insert the =
module and finally inserted the module forcefully using the command =
"insmod -f pctel" and "insmod -f ptserial" and it worked. So get the =
source code from Google and do the ./configure, make and make install =
stuff.... hope this will help you...

From praveen at symonds.net  Fri Apr  9 11:12:26 2004

Subject: [Ilugc] Re: Thankx

References: <BAY9-F65hj59Pa2bZSc00028782@hotmail.com> <40764811.10701@symonds.net> <BAY9-DAV18jVGjqNyZo0001b549@hotmail.com>

K.K.Senthil Velan wrote:

> I really Thank you for your valuable advice and instructions . But i need to
> know how to remove the "fb" module. Hope you will help me. Waiting for your
> mail.

While configuring the X server, a question like "Should I use the 
kernel's framebuffer interface?" will be asked. Say no to it. Or else, 
unselect 'fb' module in the list of modules to be loaded.

HTH.


From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Fri Apr  9 16:08:50 2004
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Sat, 10 Apr 2004 02:08:50 +1000
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: mv NewMail mbox ??
In-Reply-To: <c515km$1dm$1@sea.gmane.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404071433410.16788-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in> <c515km$1dm$1@sea.gmane.org>
Message-ID: <20040409160850.GA14528@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi,

SaravanaKumar wrote:
> Bharathi S wrote:
> >How to manually move the new mails from /var/spool/mail/$USER to
> >$USER's mbox ?
> 
> cat /var/spool/mail/$USER >> $USER/mbox
> echo ""> /var/spool/mail/$USER
> 

what happens when new mail arrives inbetween your 'cat' and your 'echo'
commands?  You end up clobbering it.  Were mailbox updating this easy, I
would be writing MTAs/MDAs/MUAs ;-)

Updating mail boxes requires carefull file locking to avoid simultaneous
updates (by mta/mda, mua, etc).  Add NFS with it's broken file locking
and it's a HUGE headache.

Since the OP has root access, it's best to shutdown the MTA for a few
seconds and ensure other precautions before performing this procedure.

Procmail can be put to work if the above is infeasible.

Also note,
    echo "" > mbox
creates a one byte file and creates a possibly invalid mbox.  To
truncate a file to zero bytes in bash, I typically do -
    :> filename

- Raja


From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Fri Apr  9 16:21:41 2004
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Sat, 10 Apr 2004 02:21:41 +1000
Subject: [Ilugc] File Tracking
In-Reply-To: <4073FC4E.4010805@symonds.net>
References: <c50tco$aae$1@sea.gmane.org> <4073FC4E.4010805@symonds.net>
Message-ID: <20040409162141.GB14528@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi,

Praveen Kumar wrote:
> SaravanaKumar wrote:
> > i want to keep track of file changes. Any tools that can track the
> > files(under specific directory) and send mail automatically.
> 
> I saw one such tool on Debian. File Alteration Monitor (FAM)

FAM may not be the tool for the job.

Think of a file manager like application that needs to refresh its
display automatically when the currently viewing directory changes.
FAM is primarily aimed at supporting such applications.  Here is what
the SGI website has to say -

 GUI tools should not mislead the user; they should display the current
 state of the system, even when changes to the system originate from
 outside of the tools themselves. FAM helps make GUI tools more usable
 by notifying them when the files they're interested in are created,
 modified, executed, and removed.

On a personal note, the original SGI famd has poor security track
record.  I would strongly recommend against famd whenever possible.

> > i read about tripwire. Is there any way i can tell tripwire to track
> > changes of all files in a directory recursively.

Tripwire is the perfect tool for the job.  Read the manuals.

- Raja


From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Fri Apr  9 16:29:13 2004
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Sat, 10 Apr 2004 02:29:13 +1000
Subject: [Ilugc] motd in X
In-Reply-To: <c53mg0$f8r$1@sea.gmane.org>
References: <c53mg0$f8r$1@sea.gmane.org>
Message-ID: <20040409162913.GC14528@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi,

SaravanaKumar wrote:
> Is there any way to display the motd files after users login in X?

If you are using xdm add the following line to /etc/X11/xdm/Xstartup.

    xmessage -file /etc/motd -geometry 640x480

For xdm clones (gdm, kdm, etc) adjust appropriately.

- Raja

Thanks for the link.  I've used Twiki and phpwiki, but MediaWiki beats
everything.  I'm downloading it now!

More than the wiki engine itself, the content is equally important.
Good content is very valuble not only for our own lug, but also the
greater community at large.  I have found answers for several of my
problems at the Wellington Lug Wiki -
    http://www.wlug.org.nz/

The "User Submitted Notes" section is outstanding -
    http://www.wlug.org.nz/UserSubmittedNotes

I request for a similar section in our Wiki.  I'm happy to contribute
whatever I can to such a section.

- Raja

From ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in  Sat Apr 10 04:23:17 2004
From: ramanraj at md4.vsnl.net.in (Ramanraj K)
Date: Sat, 10 Apr 2004 09:53:17 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Getting introduced to installations
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404061855390.28296-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in>
Message-ID: <407776B5.30502@md4.vsnl.net.in>

I got introduced to Free Software at the Banglore IT.COM 2000, and for
what it is worth I share that experience here.

The IT.COM event  was given very wide publicity  in the newspapers and
magazines.  At  the show entrance, volunteers  registered the visitors
through terminals,  and gave  an ID  Card that could  be worn,  a jute
carry  bag  and a  CD  titled  IT.COM  upon registration.   Well,  the
Registration fees was Rs.  100/- or  so [no free lunch].  The show was
many times bigger  that what Meera Dynamic does every  now and then in
Chennai,  but size  hardly matters  - there  was just  one  large Free
Software pavilion with the banner `Linux', where demos, talks, selling
cd's etc were  all happening at the same time.   The Pavilion was like
this: [please use emacs/vi to view]

+---------+------------------------------------------------------+---------+
|                 Miscellaneous  Terminals                             |
|  SuSE*                                                       Clusters 
|                             
|                                                              |
+---------+                                                            
|                             
|                                                               CAD       |
|  Mandrake*           +----------------------------+                  
|                             
|                      |     Conference Area        |                     |
+---------+            |                            |           
+---------+                 
|                      |xxx xxxxxxxxx  xxxxxxxxx xxx|                 |
|  Caldera*            |xxx xxxxxxxxx  xxxxxxxxx xxx|                 
|                          
|                      |xxx xChairsxx  xxxxxxxxx xxx|                  |
+---------+            |xxx xxxxxxxxx  xxxxxxxxx xxx|          Network 
|     
|                      |xxx xxxxxxxxx  xxxxxxxxx xxx|           Demo   |
|  RedHat*             +----------------------------+                     |
|                                                                  |
+---------+                                 +---------+
|                                                 |
|                   +--------------------------------+                   |
|                   |   CDs/Packs/T-Shirts/Selling   |   
                    |
|    Way in         |          CDROM Sales         |         Way out       |
|                   |                         |                       |
+                   +================================+   
                    +

The entire pavilion was literally free and open, with light partitions
to demarcate areas.  The terminals were showing off the nice tools and
games available on KDE.  Some  neat drawings were displayed on the CAD
terminals.  Rugged hardware machinery running the clusters were on the
floor,  unlike the  dainty PC's  that  sat on  desks.  The  volunteers
explained things  crisply, allowed  me to try  a few things,  and gave
pamplets.   This was  the first  time I  came face  to face  with free
software, and was immediately convinced  about it, and wanted to start
using it.  While walking out, I purchased a few distros - Mandrake and
some others for about Rs.100/-.

I  came back home  and tried  installing the  distros.  I  could never
install X  with the  hardware I had  then, and  could only get  to the
command prompt.  I  meanwhile got `Setting up a  Linux Server - Visual
Black  Book- Step-By-Step  Visual  Guide' by  Hide  Tsuji and  Takashi
Wantanabe, published by dreamtech Press  and got a good picture of the
things possible.  Simple commands like  cat *.txt and grep thrilled me
to no end.  Later, I had another occasion to visit Bangalore, and this
time went  in for  the SuSE  7.0 box, which  met all  my requirements.
With help from the book and the box, I set up a usable server.

Over the past 4 years, I  have downloaded sources from the internet or
got  CDs  to update  the  tools I  use.   Learning  and updating  free
software is virtually without limits, and so we are here, I guess.
 
HTH :)
Ramanraj.
__
Notes:
*This  is about my  first contact  with Gnu/Linux.   Application based
 division may make  better sense than distro based  ones.
 For example booths can be classified like this:
 Games:  icebreaker;tetris;quickcell;Mirrormagic
 Paint:  tuxpaint;gimp
 A/V:    xmms;mtv
 Dev:    emacs;vi
 Server: LAMP, Sendmail, wiki, php nuke,  etc.
 
** Please also use  wiki or something like that  to register people at
 the entrance, and for collecting comments at the exit point

Rough map drawn  with emacs - it can cut and copy rectangles:
select with  point and  mark 
C-x r c to copy rectangle
C-x r k to kill rectangle
C-x r y to paste/yank rectangle




From rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu  Thu Apr  8 18:12:37 2004
From: rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu (Sridhar R)
Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 23:42:37 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Gentoo Documentation (available)
Message-ID: <51353.203.197.138.167.1081447957.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>

If anyone is interested in Gentoo, I have mirrored up their documentation
directory.  It is available here
http://cs.annauniv.edu/~rsridhar/download/gentoo2004/gentoo-docs.tar.bz2

Thanks to wget[1]!

References
~~~
[1] I tried this
  $ cd doc/
  $ wget -p -r -np -E --convert-links http://gentoo.org/doc/en/
    (Without the -E option, it won't work)
  $ tar jcvf gentoo-docs.tar.bz2 doc/
  Simple!

R. Sridhar

On Sat, 10 Apr 2004, Raja Subramanian wrote:

> > >How to manually move the new mails from /var/spool/mail/$USER to
> > >$USER's mbox ?

> > cat /var/spool/mail/$USER >> $USER/mbox
> > echo ""> /var/spool/mail/$USER

> Updating mail boxes requires carefull file locking to avoid
> simultaneous updates (by mta/mda, mua, etc).  Add NFS with it's
> broken file locking and it's a HUGE headache.

It's gone :) (Headache)

> Procmail can be put to work if the above is infeasible.

Now Procmail fwds all my mails to my mbox :)

From arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in  Sat Apr 10 06:56:35 2004
From: arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in (Arvind Narayanan)
Date: Sat, 10 Apr 2004 12:26:35 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Fedora Core 1.0 - ready for production server ???
In-Reply-To: <1849BEAE69F5D511889100A0C9F296586A7C71@cadexchange>; from asan@lucastvs.co.in on Sat, Apr 10, 2004 at 07:38:10AM +0530
References: <1849BEAE69F5D511889100A0C9F296586A7C71@cadexchange>
Message-ID: <20040410122634.A30273@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>

On Sat, Apr 10, 2004 at 07:38:10AM +0530, asan@lucastvs.co.in wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> Anyone can suggest, can we install Fedora Core 1.0 on production server
> (live server) ??? Itz stable ??
> 
My experience with servers is limited, so take whatever I say 
with a pinch of salt.

That said, my opinion is defintely NO. First, Fedora is not intended
to be used for servers. They focus more on getting the desktop to
work right. Further, I'm not sure they iron out all the bugs before
shipping. I've seen weird behavior with the panel in gnome, for example.
On the server side, I know of one particularly horrible bug in grep
in Fedora, for that matter in RH9 as well: it takes exponential time
when the encoding is UTF-8 (default in RH9/Fedora). I've also been on
the Fedora mailing lists and IRC, and frankly, the QA process doesn't
assure much confidence. They're kind of working out the organizational
structure and things like that, and it looks like it will take another
release cycle or two before things fall smoothly in line.

On the other hand, to get bleeding edge releases of desktop software
with supremely sane defaults (I hate wasting time customizing things)
I'd go with Fedora any day.

Arvind
-- 
Q: Do you ever think about quantum computing?  
Linus: I think that's a load of bull.
(From a Linux Lunacy cruise interview. After the presumptuous disparagement
of QC, Linus goes on to confuse it with DNA computing.)
