From prasannadavid at fewanet.com.np  Thu Apr 15 17:07:34 2004
From: prasannadavid at fewanet.com.np (Prasanna David)
Date: Thu, 15 Apr 2004 22:52:34 +0545
Subject: [Ilugc] MDK10.0 ok for production server ?
In-Reply-To: <20040414143405.GA28452@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>
References: <407C186A.1000801@ntc.net.np> <20040414143405.GA28452@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>
Message-ID: <407EC156.8090101@fewanet.com.np>

>>Another question:
>>
>>Did anyone notice any problem with reiserfs in MDK9.1 ?  In 2 of our 
>>machines, the file system got messed up (some files missing, some with 
>>unrelated content, etc.) after few power-cuts.
> 
> 
> Get a UPS.
> 
> - Raja


We do have stabiliser and UPS.  Suddenly there will be a lightning 
strike somewhere (or some strong, very-quick fluctuation), and the PC 
will just reboot.  Even if the PC is behind a stabiliser and a UPS, this 
happens many times.  I have seen this behaviour with many brands of UPS. 
  Thats why I am worried about this problem.

Do you think it is a better idea to say "yes" when it asks "do you want 
to check the fs.." while rebooting ?

Is there much difference between the journaling implementation in the 
various file systems ?


(The place I am living in is sometiems called "Nepal's Chirapunji".  The 
sky will be clear and the sun shining.  After 10 minutes, you will be 
having thunder strikes and heavy showers.  And after one hour, you can't 
say that it rained some time back.  So, one can't do anything about it 
as it comes and goes very quickly.)

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Apr 16 03:25:41 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 08:55:41 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] MDK10.0 ok for production server ?
In-Reply-To: <407EC156.8090101@fewanet.com.np>
References: <407C186A.1000801@ntc.net.np> <20040414143405.GA28452@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au> <407EC156.8090101@fewanet.com.np>
Message-ID: <407F5235.9080305@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/15/2004 10:37 PM]  Prasanna David :

> We do have stabiliser and UPS.  Suddenly there will be a lightning 
> strike somewhere (or some strong, very-quick fluctuation), and the PC 
> will just reboot.  Even if the PC is behind a stabiliser and a UPS, this 
> happens many times.  I have seen this behaviour with many brands of UPS. 
>  Thats why I am worried about this problem.

The problem is that the power does not cut over to the UPS fast enough.

You need a surge suppressor as well - most high quality commercial grade 
/ isp grade power bars / power strips will have these.

> Do you think it is a better idea to say "yes" when it asks "do you want 
> to check the fs.." while rebooting ?

depends - use a journalling fs like ext3 and you should have less 
problems wrt lost data from power cuts.

	srs

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Apr 16 04:14:51 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 09:44:51 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Display name error!!
In-Reply-To: <20040415144912.5409.qmail@web60610.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040415144912.5409.qmail@web60610.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <407F5DBB.3060400@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/15/2004 8:19 PM]  S.N.Sudharsan :

>       When sending mails from yahoo, why isn`t my name
> appearing as S.N.Sudharsan(all mails originating from
> yahoomail) but is appearing in a different string
> format with the name in the middle, like
> <iso-60040-??%%S.N.Sudharsan>, though my outgoing mail
> preferences show my name appearing normally. 

that is the character set your email is being sent in

sometimes because of browser related issues when typing in stuff you 
might get some weird high ascii characters inserted into the name ..

just reset your browser's character set to iso-8859-1 or us-ascii and 
then change your name to S.N.Sudharshan again.

	srs

From anand.kumar at gavsin.com  Fri Apr 16 04:48:21 2004
From: anand.kumar at gavsin.com (Anand Kumar Saha)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 10:18:21 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Kernel Upgrade
Message-ID: <7FA74F140B180D478F3E5942BDFBADAC037A0E@chnmsg02.gavsin.com>

  | I am ready to use menuconfig or xconfig but then i would=20
  | like to know which all modules are currently loaded (how do=20
  | i come to know this) and would like to retain them.=20
  | Somebosy please tell me in general how to choose the=20
  | options. Or please give some valuable pointers.

get hold of the .config file of your current kernel. that
will tell you all about which features were built statically,
which features were built as modules, and which features
were not built.

the .config file can be found at the top level directory
of the source. i.e. where you have, among other files, the
README file.=20

that's that, given that your current kernel conf is stable.

HTH
saha
--

> hi

> authentication and Digest authentication......

> the pop screen comes and when i type the login and passwd , it gives

From praveen at symonds.net  Fri Apr 16 07:12:02 2004
From: praveen at symonds.net (Praveen Kumar)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 12:42:02 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] cd writer
In-Reply-To: <20040416054726.83785.qmail@web40102.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040416054726.83785.qmail@web40102.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <407F8742.1090908@symonds.net>

Shaks wrote:

> 1/ "cdrecord" is good from command line
> 
> 2/ http://www.k3b.org has good GUI interface
> 
> 3/ http://www.xcdroast.org is also nice

Take a look at CD-Writing HOW-TO from tldp.org before your start.

You have to turn on SCSI emulation of your CDROM drive if you are using 
an older version of cdrecord which doesn't suport ATAPI writers. (Note 
that SCSI emulation is deprecated in Kernel 2.6). For enabling this your 
have to pass "hdc=ide-scsi" to your kernel (Assuming CD writer is /dev/hdc).

An example cdrecord command string to burn an iso image (on my system) is

# cdrecord -v dev=0,0,0 speed=52 driveropts=burnfree sarge-i386-1.iso


-- 
http://puggy.symonds.net/~praveen

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Apr 16 07:15:22 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 12:45:22 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] IP Address
In-Reply-To: <20040416071019.E63E33AA46A@ws5-8.us4.outblaze.com>
References: <20040416071019.E63E33AA46A@ws5-8.us4.outblaze.com>
Message-ID: <407F880A.4040905@frodo.hserus.net>

[4/16/2004 12:40 PM]  Senthil Velan :

> Why IP addresses are represented in 32-bit patterns? Why can't we have more bits?

that is the address scheme in ipv4

look at ipv6 for "more bits"

www.ipv6.org.           1H IN CNAME     shake.stacken.kth.se.
shake.stacken.kth.se.   1H IN A         130.237.234.41
shake.stacken.kth.se.   1H IN AAAA      2001:6b0:1:ea:a00:20ff:fe8f:708f

	srs

I want to configure Apache with two application
running from the same IP address....looking at the
documentation
-----------------------------
# Listen for virtual host requests on all IP addresses
NameVirtualHost *
<VirtualHost *>
DocumentRoot /www/example1
ServerName www.example1.com

</VirtualHost>

<VirtualHost *>
DocumentRoot /www/example2
ServerName www.example2.org
# Other directives here
</VirtualHost> 

----------------------------

i configed the conf file too
---------------------------
<VirtualHost 192.168.0.30>
         ServerAdmin root@localhost
         DocumentRoot /root/vinoo/mantis-0.18.2
ServerName 192.168.0.30/mantis
ServerSignature email
         DirectoryIndex index.php index.html index.htm
index.shtml
         LogLevel debug
         HostNameLookups off
</VirtualHost>
<VirtualHost 192.168.0.30>
         ServerAdmin root@localhost
         DocumentRoot /usr/dotproject
ServerName 192.168.0.30/dotproject

         ServerSignature email
         DirectoryIndex index.php index.html index.htm
index.shtml
         LogLevel debug
         HostNameLookups off
</VirtualHost>
--------------------------------


but i am not able to run the other application
192.168.0.30/dotproject

pre-remove sound-slot-0 /bin/aumix-minimal -f /etc/.aumixrc -S

alias usb-controller1 usb-uhci

Message-ID: <20040416120542.28511.qmail@web14801.mail.yahoo.com>

hi
well ,i  make a reasonable reading and then post
questions on this forum....

yeah i took care of those chmod settings...

chmod 701 $HOME
chmod 701 $HOME/public_html
chmod 604 $HOME/public_html/index.html

vt

From prasannadavid at fewanet.com.np  Fri Apr 16 17:32:09 2004
From: prasannadavid at fewanet.com.np (Prasanna David)
Date: Fri, 16 Apr 2004 23:17:09 +0545
Subject: [Ilugc] MDK10.0 ok for production server ?
In-Reply-To: <407F5235.9080305@frodo.hserus.net>
References: <407C186A.1000801@ntc.net.np> <20040414143405.GA28452@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au> <407EC156.8090101@fewanet.com.np> <407F5235.9080305@frodo.hserus.net>
Message-ID: <40801899.8090503@fewanet.com.np>

Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> [4/15/2004 10:37 PM]  Prasanna David :
> 
>> We do have stabiliser and UPS.  Suddenly there will be a lightning 
>> strike somewhere (or some strong, very-quick fluctuation), and the PC 
>> will just reboot.  Even if the PC is behind a stabiliser and a UPS, 
>> this happens many times.  I have seen this behaviour with many brands 
>> of UPS.  Thats why I am worried about this problem.
> 
> 
> The problem is that the power does not cut over to the UPS fast enough.
> 
> You need a surge suppressor as well - most high quality commercial grade 
> / isp grade power bars / power strips will have these.
> 
Thanks a lot.  I will look for that.

>> Do you think it is a better idea to say "yes" when it asks "do you 
>> want to check the fs.." while rebooting ?
> 
> 
> depends - use a journalling fs like ext3 and you should have less 
> problems wrt lost data from power cuts.
> 

But this kind of data loss happend with reiserfs !  Well, I haven't 
tried with other distributions, but this kind of mess up happened in MDK 
9.1 reiserfs partitions atleast twice.

Some other systems are also running MDK9.1 but with ext3.  Nothing like 
that happened (so far).

I wanted to use reiserfs since I felt that would give better performance 
for our pattern of files/usage.

Prasanna David

In-Reply-To: <1849BEAE69F5D511889100A0C9F296586A7C71@cadexchange>
References: <1849BEAE69F5D511889100A0C9F296586A7C71@cadexchange>
Message-ID: <20040417062147.GA32102@cok.wiltechsoftware.com>

On Sat, Apr 10, 2004 at 07:38:10AM +0530, asan@lucastvs.co.in wrote:

>>>Anyone can  suggest, can we  install Fedora Core 1.0  on production
>>>server (live server) ??? Itz stable ??

The stability of a server depends on various factors. 

* Operating System running on that
* Latest Security updates
* A clueful Administrator

Essence: Whether it is RHL or  Fedora or Debian, stability of a server
depends on the person and the way he handles it.

From: rsridhar at cs.annauniv.edu (Sridhar R)
Date: Sun, 18 Apr 2004 23:45:02 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] `mail` - Resource unavailable
Message-ID: <36225.203.197.138.167.1082312102.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>

Today I wrote a script to send all  users about their account Info.  There
were about 500 users.  But in the middle, error messages came
"Resource temporarily unavailable"
** repeatedly (for a set of users in the middle) **

So the mail is reached only to small group of users.  I am wondering why
this happens.
CPU Info
~~
Pentium III, 1 GHz, 256KB cache, 1GB Ram

The script I have used is here
http://cs.annauniv.edu/~rsridhar/sendletter.py


-- 
R. Sridhar



From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Apr 19 10:52:53 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 16:22:53 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] `mail` - Resource unavailable
References: <36225.203.197.138.167.1082312102.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
Message-ID: <080a01c425fc$788bf140$0201a8c0@hserus.net>

Sridhar R <rsridhar@cs.annauniv.edu> wrote:
> Today I wrote a script to send all  users about their account Info.
> There were about 500 users.  But in the middle, error messages came
> "Resource temporarily unavailable"
> ** repeatedly (for a set of users in the middle) **
>
> So the mail is reached only to small group of users.  I am wondering
> why this happens.

The mail will be queued for another attempt, if you have injected all
these into local sendmail.

> http://cs.annauniv.edu/~rsridhar/sendletter.py

you are essentially calling 500 instances of /bin/mail?

anyway that calls the local sendmail.

do a "mailq" and see - the rest of the mail will be queued for later
delivery I guess.

    srs

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

From dileep at kumarayil.net  Mon Apr 19 11:28:40 2004
From: dileep at kumarayil.net (Dileep M. Kumar)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 16:58:40 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] debian unstable apt mirros
In-Reply-To: <49994.203.197.138.167.1082313694.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
References: <49994.203.197.138.167.1082313694.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
Message-ID: <20040419112840.GA943@cok.wiltechsoftware.com>

On Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 12:11:34AM +0530, Sridhar R wrote:

>>>I have checked out the mirors  list in debian.org.  I tried most of
>>>them in  /etc/apt/sources.list.  But none  succeeded in downloading
>>>package indexes

deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ unstable main non-free contrib
deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ unstable main non-free contrib
deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US unstable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb-src http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US unstable/non-US main contrib non-free

should work.

Regards
-- 
 .''`.     Dileep M. Kumar <dileep@kumarayil.net>
: :'  :    http://www.kumarayil.net
`. `'`     Mobile: 98474-47437
  `-  Debian GNU/Linux - Choice of the Freedom Lovers

Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


Hi,
you might want to look at the apt-howto. Google for the apt-howto.

There is a tool called  netselect-apt.

I am attaching the information as text file. I did a copy and paste from
the debian website for using it at home. I havent tried it yet.

(See attached file: apt-howto.txt)

This  file is only a partial version and covers netselect which can help u
set up your sources.list

Regards,
Sanjay

	name="apt-howto.txt"

Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64

From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Mon Apr 19 13:09:09 2004
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 23:09:09 +1000
Subject: [Ilugc] debian unstable apt mirros
In-Reply-To: <20040419112840.GA943@cok.wiltechsoftware.com>
References: <49994.203.197.138.167.1082313694.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu> <20040419112840.GA943@cok.wiltechsoftware.com>
Message-ID: <20040419130909.GA26714@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi,

Dileep M. Kumar wrote:
> On Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 12:11:34AM +0530, Sridhar R wrote:
> 
> >>>I have checked out the mirors  list in debian.org.  I tried most of
> >>>them in  /etc/apt/sources.list.  But none  succeeded in downloading
> >>>package indexes
> 
> deb http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ unstable main non-free contrib
> deb-src http://ftp.us.debian.org/debian/ unstable main non-free contrib
> deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US unstable/non-US main contrib non-free
> deb-src http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US unstable/non-US main contrib non-free

Most Indian internet providers (dishnet/touchtel) are very well connected
to Singapore.  The NUS mirror is pretty quick on my touchtel line.

deb ftp://mirror.nus.edu.sg/pub/Debian stable main contrib non-free
deb ftp://mirror.nus.edu.sg/pub/Debian-non-US stable/non-US main contrib non-free
deb http://security.debian.org/ woody/updates main

- Raja

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Mon Apr 19 13:37:41 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 19:07:41 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Internet Connection
References: <49254.203.197.138.167.1082381455.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
Message-ID: <0a4301c42613$7e4f5920$0201a8c0@hserus.net>

Sridhar R <rsridhar@cs.annauniv.edu> wrote:
> 1. Hathway - http://www.hathway.com/bci/packages.htm

standard cablemodems, you'd just plug an ethernet connection into your
pc

> 2. Touchtel - no support under linux (they won't provide/support old
> modems)
> 3. dishnet - NOINFO - dishnetdsl.com is not loading at all

touchtel and dishnet will both give you USB modems which do have third
party linux drivers - search at http://eciadsl.flashtux.org (that page
is in french, click the uk flag on the top right hand corner of the site
to get the english version)

Dishnet also has a (more expensive) "broadband router" option, which
does PPPoA (at least in dishnet's case) and gives you an ethernet port
that you can plug into your linux box.

> I need internet connection that has no time limit (buy may be data
>  limit). Can anyone suggest a good one?  ... and I feel difficult to
> pay more than Rs. 1000/- per month.
> Any thoughts?

Dishnet has a data limit of 1 gb per month.

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

Chandrakanth Chereddi <kanth@gmx.net> wrote:
> On Mon, 19 Apr 2004 10:02:23 +0530
> Sitaram Chamarty <sitaram@atc.tcs.co.in> wrote:
>
>> Let me also add this: I have been badly burned by one cable company
>> (Hathway) and had to get rid of them in disgust after weeks of
>> fighting with them over how many MB I had actually downloaded; they
>> have some major screwup in how they count "bytes downloaded by
>> customer" that I could not get them to admit.  I actually lost quite
>> a bit of money in that deal, but I preferred to cut my losses rather
>> than be gouged every month on charges for extra MBs that I had not
>> downloaded!
>
> You bet!!! These calculations are a major screw up. As SRS pointed
> out, the ARP and other gutter broadcasts (if you use windows, NetBEUI
> broadcasts) and ICMP to the local gateway are all counted. For the
> calculation to be correct at the gateway they should be loggin data
> transfer with src or dst from external networks only. For example, if
> you always keep pinging your gateway to check connectivity and they
> count that too as usage you are in for some major surprises. More
> often than not their limits, a GB or 500 MB are too less if you
> consider
> normal usage (I consider myself as normal :D). You can always argue
> with these types now, after the BSNL only internet phone line cost
> being very affordable and you can transfer quite a bit. A simple
> calculation might help, suppose you get an average speed of 2.5 kilo
> bytes per sec. You
> can transfer 2.5x60x60 kbytes per hour = 8.8 MB per hr. If you use 10
> hours of internet per day this is about 80 MB per day. And per month
> considering 24 working days 80*24 = 1900 MB almost 2 GB and you pay
> way less than the so called cable ISPs with the transfer calculations.
>
> However you can never get more than 4 KB at any given time on dial up
> considering normal dialup line quality in India. The only reason why I
> too use cable, albiet without any transfer caps.
>
> HTH.
> CCK./

My touchtel provided dsl modem terminates with ethernet and is setup to
work as a network bridge.  I have not tried the touchtel USB modems
under Linux (which I suspect will be a major pain, getting the my
earlier Dishnet USB modem to work was also a huge headache).

Btw, I heard rumour that Touchtel is planning on abandoning the USB
modems in favour of the ethernet ones.  Good news for linux-ers.

From rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au  Mon Apr 19 15:12:11 2004
From: rsubr at pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au (Raja Subramanian)
Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 01:12:11 +1000
Subject: [Ilugc] apt-get dist-upgrade - interuption
In-Reply-To: <44316.203.197.138.167.1082380570.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
References: <44316.203.197.138.167.1082380570.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu>
Message-ID: <20040419151211.GB31348@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au>

Hi,

Sridhar R wrote:
> 
> I am running
> 
>  $ apt-get dist-upgrade  (~250MB)
> 
> now.  I am running it through GNU screen (in case if the client get
> crashed).  But what would happen if in the middle of setting up packages,
> the server crashed.  What would happen to the state of debian?  Will it be
> fault tolerant?

It's highly unlikely that your box will crash due to software problems.
But it still depends what you are upgrading to.  Upgrading between
stable releases (eg. potato -> woody) is *extremely* robust.  IIRC the
potato to woody update did not even require a reboot!

I've upgraded several boxes from woody to sarge without any major dramas
(expect XFree86 to fall over, but that's pretty much it).

Recovering from hardware problems, or a power failure depends on the
filesystem you are running and a number of other factors.

In any case, your upgrade session can be resumed with -
    apt-get dist-upgrade  # this will pickup where it left off
    apt-get -f install    # finish installing any pending debs

Note: Apt stores its downloads in /var/cache/apt/archive so you can
      easily save your downloaded files for future use.

- Raja


From arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in  Mon Apr 19 15:18:17 2004
From: arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in (Arvind Narayanan)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 20:48:17 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Internet Connection
In-Reply-To: <0b6a01c4261c$50cdf070$0201a8c0@hserus.net>; from linux@frodo.hserus.net on Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 08:10:50PM +0530
References: <49254.203.197.138.167.1082381455.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu> <20040419192312.B29418@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in> <0b6a01c4261c$50cdf070$0201a8c0@hserus.net>
Message-ID: <20040419204817.A31645@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>

On Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 08:10:50PM +0530, Suresh Ramasubramanian wrote:
> Arvind Narayanan <arvindn@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in> wrote:
> > On Mon, Apr 19, 2004 at 07:00:55PM +0530, Sridhar R wrote:
> >
> >> Hathway is cable internet, so trusting that is in doubt.
> >
> > What has trust in the company got to do with the technology?
> >
> >> Any happy hathway customer?
> >
> > Yup. Me. YMMV.
> 
> this thread on ilughyd should soon dissolve some of your happiness
Oh it would? I'm just saying my experience has been positive, other
people are free to decide for themselves and my opinion is not
based on their experience.

Anyway the complaints below don't make much sense, because the
question of how much you "actually" downloaded is meaningless.
The metering is done right in the modem, and it counts everything
that comes in, applying no intelligence. They told me that right
at the beginning. If you're fine with that, go for it. Otherwise
there's no deal. 

Anyway I spend hours online everyday, and I don't even exceed
300 MB. And calculations starting with "say you download 2.5
KB per second" are utter nonsense, because your sustained BW
is going to be far less than that (unless you're downloading
mp3s etc. If you want to do such things you're definitely going to
get screwed.) My usage pattern is mostly browsing and ssh (typing
this over ssh, BTW; almost unnoticeably low latency, which I 
never got over dialup) and it suits me just fine.

Tell you what, this person probably had a windows machine which
was infected with spyware/worms which were downloading god-knows-what.
That's how they'd have got 2GB.

Arvind

Subject: [Ilugc] Internet Connection
References: <49254.203.197.138.167.1082381455.squirrel@cs.annauniv.edu> <20040419192312.B29418@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in> <0b6a01c4261c$50cdf070$0201a8c0@hserus.net> <20040419204817.A31645@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>
Message-ID: <00cc01c42632$d4d314c0$0201a8c0@hserus.net>

Arvind Narayanan <arvindn@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in> wrote:
> Tell you what, this person probably had a windows machine which
> was infected with spyware/worms which were downloading god-knows-what.
> That's how they'd have got 2GB.

FYI the guy is using linux, doing no more than downloading standard
updates and patches (which on slackware tend to be few and well thought
out) ...

Try downloading a lot of mail over imap, just for instance.  I download
close to 40..50 megs of work related email (all of it spam, given that
my job is spam filtering) every day :)

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)


From gnutuxie at linux.net  Mon Apr 19 18:28:58 2004
From: gnutuxie at linux.net (Mahesh M)
Date: Mon, 19 Apr 2004 11:28:58 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [Ilugc] Mandrake not starting X correctly
Message-ID: <20040419182858.D94237278@sitemail.everyone.net>

Hi,

I have an Intel 865GLC motherboard with onboard graphics. I first tried to run X in redhat9 and then in fedora core1, but in vain. Finally I tried installing mandrake 10 community and i didn't even get the graphical installation. but the installation was successful. it asked for the third disk, i dont have one, so skipped that. whenever the GUI is starting up it shows up as totally glarred or something weird. madrakesoft.com says it 10 supports 865GLC.
Some of you please help me have a look at linux. This is my new computer and I just upgraded my old computer to this one to work in linux faster and better. but now it is not all working. I need help.

Thanks in advance,
Mahesh.
gnutuxie@linux.net

From shriramrsampat at yahoo.co.in  Tue Apr 20 04:37:20 2004
From: shriramrsampat at yahoo.co.in (=?iso-8859-1?q?SHRIRAM=20SAMPAT?=)
Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 05:37:20 +0100 (BST)
Subject: [Ilugc] re: Mandrake X Problem
Message-ID: <20040420043720.69461.qmail@web8203.mail.in.yahoo.com>

Hi,

There are a few things that you have to check and
correct before making x work correctly.

1. go to your BIOS and check how much memory it has
allocated for VIDEO. if it is 1MB or lesser, then you
have no chance of making X work in a resolution
greater than 640x480(8 bit).so, change it to  8 MB. if
the 8 mb option is not available, upgrade your bios
from the motherboard manufacturer website.(since yours
is new, it must have that option).

2. Choose your graphic driver as VESA in xf86config
file or any other utility that you might use. The
other things must be same, just change the driver
feild alone to VESA.

now you have a very fat chance of making it work. IF
not mail me with full details at
shriram@hcl.teradyne.com and iwill try my best to help
you. ( i myself faced these problems a month ago).


shriram

ps : PCQLinux derived from red hat fedora core-1 works
like a magic on i845/865 motherboards so why dont you
try that!!!?.

________________________________________________________________________

My tariff is 995 per month, 128kbps, 350 MB free download (up and down).
(Well, it is a different matter altogether, that ever since I went Linux, I
haven't been able to hook my comp on to the net, and hence, this month, I am
going to pay Touchtel 995 bucks for free!)

Rajendran.

        > Are you using the modem being now-provided by touchtel? Seems like
        > there are not linux-drivers for that ... how u are going about
using
        > it?

        My touchtel provided dsl modem terminates with ethernet and is setup
to
        work as a network bridge. I have not tried the touchtel USB modems
        under Linux (which I suspect will be a major pain, getting the my
        earlier Dishnet USB modem to work was also a huge headache).

        Btw, I heard rumour that Touchtel is planning on abandoning the USB
        modems in favour of the ethernet ones. Good news for linux-ers.

        - Raja

Touchtel's 995/- per month is for the USB connection (no known Linux driv=
ers
for the Zyxel Prestige 630 USB modem they ram down your throat with). Min=
=2E
2495/- per month + ST for the ADSL Router which (when setup as a bridge)
gives you an OS independent Ethernet connection to the Net. They also giv=
e 2
static IPs and 10 mail ids for you to play with.=0D
=0D
-------Original Message-------=0D
 =0D
From: rajendran=0D
Date: Tuesday, April 20, 2004 10:57:52 AM=0D
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in=0D
Subject: RE: [Ilugc] Internet Connection=0D
 =0D
My tariff is 995 per month, 128kbps, 350 MB free download (up and down).=0D
(Well, it is a different matter altogether, that ever since I went Linux,=
 I
haven't been able to hook my comp on to the net, and hence, this month, I=
 am
going to pay Touchtel 995 bucks for free!)=0D
:-(=0D
 =0D
Rajendran.=0D
 =0D

Touchtel charges minimum 2495/- per month, though. Plus service tax for 1=
=2E25
Gb transfers at 512 kbps. You pay extra for more usage/transfers.=0D
 =0D
-------Original Message-------=0D
 =0D
From: Raja Subramanian=0D
Date: Monday, April 19, 2004 08:30:38 PM=0D
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in=0D
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] debian unstable apt mirros=0D

Sridhar R wrote:=0D
> Are you using the modem being now-provided by touchtel? Seems like=0D
> there are not linux-drivers for that ... how u are going about using=0D
> it?=0D
 =0D
My touchtel provided dsl modem terminates with ethernet and is setup to=0D
work as a network bridge. I have not tried the touchtel USB modems=0D
under Linux (which I suspect will be a major pain, getting the my=0D
earlier Dishnet USB modem to work was also a huge headache).=0D
 =0D
Btw, I heard rumour that Touchtel is planning on abandoning the USB=0D
modems in favour of the ethernet ones. Good news for linux-ers.=0D
 =0D

From ramesh at rhytha.com  Tue Apr 20 06:33:06 2004
From: ramesh at rhytha.com (Muthukumar Prakasham)
Date: Tue, 20 Apr 2004 12:03:06 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Internet Connection
In-Reply-To: <4084BB2E.000009.66901@srl.ho.plworldways.com>

------=_NextPart_001_0114_01C426CF.7456D530
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

What is the per month bandwidth u get from touchtel for 2495/pm.
 
regards
 
Ramesh

  _____  

From: ilugc-admin@ae.iitm.ac.in [mailto:ilugc-admin@ae.iitm.ac.in] On Behalf
Of Shankar Lakshmanan
Sent: Tuesday, April 20, 2004 11:25 AM
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
Subject: RE: [Ilugc] Internet Connection



Touchtel's 995/- per month is for the USB connection (no known Linux drivers
for the Zyxel Prestige 630 USB modem they ram down your throat with). Min.
2495/- per month + ST for the ADSL Router which (when setup as a bridge)
gives you an OS independent Ethernet connection to the Net. They also give 2
static IPs and 10 mail ids for you to play with.
 
-------Original Message-------
 
From: rajendran <mailto:rajendran@xerago.com> 
Date: Tuesday, April 20, 2004 10:57:52 AM
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
Subject: RE: [Ilugc] Internet Connection
 
My tariff is 995 per month, 128kbps, 350 MB free download (up and down).
(Well, it is a different matter altogether, that ever since I went Linux, I
haven't been able to hook my comp on to the net, and hence, this month, I am
going to pay Touchtel 995 bucks for free!)
:-(
 
Rajendran.
 
-----Original Message-----
From: ilugc-admin@ae.iitm.ac.in [mailto:ilugc-admin@ae.iitm.ac.in]On Behalf
Of Shankar Lakshmanan
Sent: Tuesday, April 20, 2004 10:38 AM
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] Internet Connection



Touchtel charges minimum 2495/- per month, though. Plus service tax for 1.25
Gb transfers at 512 kbps. You pay extra for more usage/transfers.
 
-------Original Message-------
 
From: Raja  <mailto:rsubr@pcomm.hfi.unimelb.edu.au> Subramanian
Date: Monday, April 19, 2004 08:30:38 PM
To: ilugc@ae.iitm.ac.in
Subject: Re: [Ilugc] debian unstable apt mirros
 
Hi,
 
Sridhar R wrote:
> Are you using the modem being now-provided by touchtel? Seems like
> there are not linux-drivers for that ... how u are going about using
> it?
 
My touchtel provided dsl modem terminates with ethernet and is setup to
work as a network bridge. I have not tried the touchtel USB modems
under Linux (which I suspect will be a major pain, getting the my
earlier Dishnet USB modem to work was also a huge headache).
 
Btw, I heard rumour that Touchtel is planning on abandoning the USB
modems in favour of the ethernet ones. Good news for linux-ers.
 
- Raja

Down below in this thread I have mentioned, Touchtel's 2495/- per month g=
ets
you 1.25 Gb of upstream/downstream transfers per month.  You pay extra fo=
r
more transfers. Line speeds are at 512 kbps. =0D

Of Shankar Lakshmanan=0D

=0D
Touchtel's 995/- per month is for the USB connection (no known Linux driv=
ers
for the Zyxel Prestige 630 USB modem they ram down your throat with). Min=
=2E
2495/- per month + ST for the ADSL Router which (when setup as a bridge)
gives you an OS independent Ethernet connection to the Net. They also giv=
e 2
static IPs and 10 mail ids for you to play with.=0D
 =0D

 I
haven't been able to hook my comp on to the net, and hence, this month, I=

going to pay Touchtel 995 bucks for free!)=0D

earlier Dishnet USB modem to work was also a huge headache).=0D

Hi,

I tried plugging in one usb smartcard reader and 
hotplug first loaded the kernel module and also called
the startup script without any hitches. I then plugged
in the second device (usb smartcard reader). since the
same driver supports multiple device instances, the
driver successfully enumerated and created a new entry
in /proc/devices. since the module is already loaded,
the corresponding script in hotplug is not getting
called. i have written the script to create an entry
in /dev directory for my reader. is there anyway to
achieve this without modifying the souce in the
hotplug.functions script?

thx in advance
Joe

Shankar Lakshmanan wrote:

> Touchtel's 995/- per month is for the USB connection (no known 
> Linux drivers for the Zyxel Prestige 630 USB modem they ram down your 
> throat with). Min. 2495/- per month + ST for the ADSL Router which 
> (when setup as a bridge) gives you an OS independent Ethernet 
> connection to the Net. They also give 2 static IPs and 10 mail ids for 
> you to play with.

At 08:22 AM 4/21/2004, Ashwin D wrote:
>These are ludicrous prices!! Hathway is perhaps better. Rs 1000 gets you
>128kbps and 750 MB. Rs 1500 gets you 1 GB.. but then again this doesnt
>include modem which is another 300 I think... But these prices are all
>terrible - cant keep a sid box updated enough :)

The prices are for touchtel's "broadband router" option - where you get 
1:4, 1:2 or even 1:1 shared ports for a dsl.

Touchtel's usb modem options are far cheaper, and closer in line to 
Hathway's prices - btw, hathway doesn't say how many people share that 128 
kbps pipe, I notice ...

         srs

> > month gets you 1.25 Gb of upstream/downstream transfers per month.
> > You pay extra for more transfers. Line speeds are at 512 kbps.


From bharathi at lantana.tenet.res.in  Wed Apr 21 03:32:33 2004
From: bharathi at lantana.tenet.res.in (Bharathi S)
Date: Wed, 21 Apr 2004 09:02:33 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] Fw: Anomalous things
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404210855170.19141-100000@lantana.iitm.ernet.in>

NETWORK WORLD NEWSLETTER: GIBBS & BRADNER 04/13/04

Today's focus:  Anomalous things

By Mark Gibbs

Anomalous Message: "An unexpected error has occurred."  - An
unexpected message unexpectedly produced by Microsoft Word.
 
> The error message I quote above fascinates me in a strange and
> unwholesome way because it raises all sorts of questions: If the
> error is unexpected are there errors that are expected? And if there
> is such a thing as an expected error, couldn't someone prevent it
> from happening?
> 
> Moreover, when an unexpected error happens how do you know it is
> actually an error rather than being perhaps an unexpected feature .
> . . because if it is unexpected, how can you know if it is an error
> or not?
> 
> This reminds me of my previous favorite error message: "Error:  No
> error," which Windows used to occasionally show and is available for
> your pleasure on various other platforms (go to Weird Error Messages
> - <http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?WeirdErrorMessages> - for an explanation
> of the Windows version). But I digress . . .
> 
> What really gets me is that despite searching the 'Net, I can find
> no reference to this exact message from Word because the text "An
> unexpected error has occurred" wasn't accompanied by any other
> explanations for my error (or should that be "non-error"). There was
> no status code, no supporting explanation - simply that lean and
> hungry-looking, Zen-like, philosophically challenging, totally
> unhelpful text that preceded Word disappearing along with my
> document rather like your drinking buddies disappearing when that
> huge bar bill appears.
> 
> Anomalous Relationship: "We are both big developers of intellectual
> property. We both own lots of patents."  - Microsoft CEO Steve
> Ballmer referring to a commonality between his company and Sun that
> really doesn't explain their new accord (
> <http://www.nwfusion.com/news/2004/0402sunsettl.html> ) unless you
> understand the subtext.
> 
> The day after April Fool's Day we saw a fine exhibition of the old
> Italian saying, "Keep your friends close and your enemies closer,"
> as Ballmer and Scott McNealy, CEO of Sun, hugged each other, swapped
> Red Wings jerseys and declared, "We do both believe in intellectual
> property."
> 
> Let me rephrase that statement: "We do both believe that open source
> in general and Linux in particular are real threats to our
> businesses."
> 
> So to settle Sun's outstanding law suit against Microsoft over the
> latter's fast and loose ways with Java, Microsoft shook $1.2 billion
> out of its coffee fund and Sun suddenly had a new best friend.
> 
> In the light of McNealy having dressed up as a penguin way back in
> 2002 ( <http://www.nwfusion.com/nlgibrad32> ), the newfound
> friendship reeks of desperation and opportunism on Sun's part and
> business as usual at Microsoft. Might Microsoft buy Sun?  Hmm.
> 
> Anomalous Legalities: "IBM's untimely responses to discovery have
> hindered orderly prosecution of the case."  - The SCO Group's
> lawyers trying to make the company's case against Big Blue sound
> like normal business - which might well be how it actually is for
> them.
> 
> SCO, in its ongoing efforts to tick off as many people as possible
> for as long as possible, is trying to drag out its case against IBM
> by asking the judge to slide the trial from the currently scheduled
> April 2005 to September 2005. SCO says IBM isn't cooperating with
> the discovery process, while IBM says SCO is being unreasonable in
> asking for every version of Unix it ever had anything to do with.
> 
> The fact that after all this time SCO refuses to substantiate its
> claims of copyright infringement in Linux (the company first sued
> IBM more than a year ago) continues to make SCO look like Mafia
> hoods trying to shake down neighborhood business owners.
 
Mark Gibbs <http://www.gibbs.com/mgbio>

-- 
Bharathi S, www.MidasComm.com,
Intel Lab,  TeNeT, IIT-Madras.

Known is drop, Unknown is OCEAN.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Thu Apr 22 02:36:32 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Thu, 22 Apr 2004 08:06:32 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Re (2) Internet Options
In-Reply-To: <20040421164201.26462.qmail@web40102.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20040421164201.26462.qmail@web40102.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <40872FB0.4020208@frodo.hserus.net>

Shaks wrote:

> DSL can be my last option. I am still looking at other
> ISP options, but, I would definitely need a router.
> Have quite a few machines that I would like to connect
> to the Internet and router/NAT protection is very
> important for me :)

The dsl router that dishnet gives you is a crappy aztech 906e - but it 
certainly does NAT, port forwarding etc, and can be telneted into if you 
want to configure it by hand.

Just pick up a simple 10/100 switch and connect the wan port of the 
switch to the ethernet port on your broadband router.

If you want, pick up a small $75 wireless AP from somewhere - especially 
if you have a laptop with wifi.

> I am also looking for web hosting services running
> Linux/UNIX servers. Do you guyz recommend anyone? Even
> a 30MB space for a good deal will be great! 

http://www.pair.com is good.  They are not the cheapest around, but 
still quite ok.

	srs

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)

From sabarinews at gawab.com  Fri Apr 23 06:12:16 2004

Linux server but i cannot send any mails in that server it is display one
error message that is

Your server has unexpectedly terminated the connection. Possible causes for
this include server problems, network problems, or a long period of

SMTP, Port: 25, Secure(SSL): No, Error Number: 0x800CCC0F

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Apr 23 01:35:31 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 07:05:31 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Mail Server Configuration Problem
In-Reply-To: <003901c428fa$0561b140$0200a8c0@info2>
References: <001301c4225c$9f6c3160$546841db@sriram> <003901c428fa$0561b140$0200a8c0@info2>
Message-ID: <408872E3.4030702@frodo.hserus.net>

Sabari Nathan wrote:

> Your server has unexpectedly terminated the connection. Possible causes for
> this include server problems, network problems, or a long period of
> inactivity. Account: '192.168.0.3 (1)', Server: '192.168.0.3', Protocol:
> SMTP, Port: 25, Secure(SSL): No, Error Number: 0x800CCC0F

set up sendmail to relay for your lan ip address space.

in /etc/mail/access -

192.168.0 [press tab] RELAY

Then save the file and do this -

# makemap hash /etc/mail/access.db < access

-- 
linux@frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
jaharkes@ravel:/usr/src$ mv linux Gnu/Linux
mv: cannot move `linux' to `Gnu/Linux': No such file or directory
	jaharkes @ cs.cmu.edu in reply to RMS on linux.kernel

From rajendran at xerago.com  Fri Apr 23 02:26:20 2004
From: rajendran at xerago.com (rajendran)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 07:56:20 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Opening Google..
Message-ID: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINAEDGDFAA.rajendran@xerago.com>

Hi All,

Was searching for something very very desperately. And, quite unusually,
Google kept throwing the towel in. (Well, I wasn't searching for something
trivial. I was searching for content on how Google does its dance).

Then suddenly I realized that for all the goodwill that Google seems to have
garnered, it is not open, and hence, by default, suspect.

Searched (using Google, talk about irony!) for an open source search engine,
a community-developed effort where we know what we are searching AS WELL AS
how we are searching.

The only risk/disadvantage would be the computing power and the
storage-space needed to host this decidedly non-decentralizable behemoth.

Found this though:-
============================================================================
=========
Ideas for an Open Search Engine Index

If you're interested in the idea of a community-built search engine, you may
want to wander over and investigate the offerings at Open Index (
http://www.openindex.org/ ). This site is not a specific project for
building an open search engine index, but more a gathering place for ideas
and pointers to various information.

At the moment this site offers discussion forums (not very active), an
overview of the Internet and indexes (how about sourcing some of these page
estimates?) thoughts about defining and designing an ideal index, and some
links. As I said, there isn't much here yet. But I hope this site stirs up
some interest in the search community and maybe some responses from its
leaders.
============================================================================
=========

Rajendran.


From arvino_55 at yahoo.com  Thu Apr 22 01:06:52 2004
From: arvino_55 at yahoo.com (Arvind Ramasamy)
Date: Wed, 21 Apr 2004 18:06:52 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [Ilugc] hotplug multiple device support
Message-ID: <20040422010652.64066.qmail@web42003.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi,

I guess what you have in mind in running a script to
create inode-entries is to map the devices to user's
static view-point of the device namespace. If that's
the case, consider a mounted-pipe / STREAMS device
and a daemon combination to invoke your script
functionality. This would make your device-interface
non-generic, but cleaner and more effective than a
post-install script ( which will be called only on
module load ).

DevFS would do the job if you provide library based
API for implementing identity-mapping using your
proc data. Somewhat like the ALSA model for sound.

- arvind <arvind@acarlab.com>



	
		
__________________________________

unless I am mistaken, I think you have to add an MX record in your DNS
server  which qualifies your mail server.

ex if 192.168.0.1 is the mail server, you have to add an MX record for the
same in your DNS machine and only then it should proceed.
I maybe wrong....srs would be able to help you better.

Tom Jose Tharayil wrote:

> unless I am mistaken, I think you have to add an MX record in your DNS
> server  which qualifies your mail server.
> 
> ex if 192.168.0.1 is the mail server, you have to add an MX record for the
> same in your DNS machine and only then it should proceed.
> I maybe wrong....srs would be able to help you better.

mx records are for receiving email from the internet.

they have no relation on who / who isnt authorized to send email through 
a particular mailserver

From arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in  Fri Apr 23 05:02:00 2004
From: arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in (Arvind Narayanan)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 10:32:00 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Opening Google..
In-Reply-To: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINAEDGDFAA.rajendran@xerago.com>; from rajendran@xerago.com on Fri, Apr 23, 2004 at 07:56:20AM +0530
References: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINAEDGDFAA.rajendran@xerago.com>
Message-ID: <20040423103200.A13581@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>

On Fri, Apr 23, 2004 at 07:56:20AM +0530, rajendran wrote:
 
> Searched (using Google, talk about irony!) for an open source search engine,
> a community-developed effort where we know what we are searching AS WELL AS
> how we are searching.

While 'open source search engine' has a nice ring to it, it isn't
very meaningful, any more than 'open source house' is.

Suppose google published what they claim to be their source code
and said its GPL'd. Now what? How do you know that its actually
what they're running? Duplicate their 100,000 machine server farm
and verify it? (yes, 100,000.) And if you're not happy with google
what do you do? How does the source code help you?

Wake me up when hardware gets cheap enough for hobbyists to buy
enough memory to store the whole web.

> The only risk/disadvantage would be the computing power and the
> storage-space needed to host this decidedly non-decentralizable behemoth.

You say this is "decidedly non-decentralizable", yet the website
you've pointed to below says that it is concerned exclusively with
distributed efforts. I think it might be better to get some idea
of what we're talking about first.

This is an issue of trust, not sofware; a social, not a technical
concern. The only way out of your problem is for everyone to operate
their own search engine. Duh.

Arvind

> 
> Found this though:-
> ============================================================================
> =========
> Ideas for an Open Search Engine Index
> 
> If you're interested in the idea of a community-built search engine, you may
> want to wander over and investigate the offerings at Open Index (
> http://www.openindex.org/ ). This site is not a specific project for
> building an open search engine index, but more a gathering place for ideas
> and pointers to various information.
> 
> At the moment this site offers discussion forums (not very active), an
> overview of the Internet and indexes (how about sourcing some of these page
> estimates?) thoughts about defining and designing an ideal index, and some
> links. As I said, there isn't much here yet. But I hope this site stirs up
> some interest in the search community and maybe some responses from its
> leaders.
> ============================================================================
> =========
> 
> Rajendran.

From linux at frodo.hserus.net  Fri Apr 23 06:04:59 2004
From: linux at frodo.hserus.net (Suresh Ramasubramanian)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 11:34:59 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] SMTP error
In-Reply-To: <58259.203.197.138.167.1082700055.squirrel@203.197.138.167>
References: <58259.203.197.138.167.1082700055.squirrel@203.197.138.167>
Message-ID: <4088B20B.3070400@frodo.hserus.net>

Sridhar R wrote:

> I updated to debian unstable, but SMTP stopped working.  After telneting
> to the server at port 25 I get this,
> 
> 220 cs.annauniv.edu ESMTP Sendmail 8.12.11/8.12.11/Debain-4; Fri, 23 Apr
> 11:23:34 +0530; (No UCE/UBE) logging access from:
> [10.1.14.73](Fail)-[10.1.14.73]
> 
> Why is the term `Fail` comming above?

There is no reverse dns (PTR) entry for the ip 10.1.14.73

You (or rather whatever random script you used to configure sendmail) 
has gone and set sendmail up to refuse mail from IPs without reverse dns

	srs

From rajendran at xerago.com  Fri Apr 23 06:57:29 2004
From: rajendran at xerago.com (rajendran)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 12:27:29 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Opening Google..
In-Reply-To: <20040423103200.A13581@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>
Message-ID: <LAEEKJKAGLFCOHMNNIINEEEKDFAA.rajendran@xerago.com>

Well Arvind,
I don't know why you are picking on me like this for an innocent post.
Anyway, now that you dragged me into it, some more "thoughts"...

>>>>>>>>>While 'open source search engine' has a nice ring to it, it isn't
>>>>>>>>>very meaningful, any more than 'open source house' is.

I don't know how you got the idea that I searched for an open source search
engine,
by typing in "open source search engine". :-(

>>>>>>>>>Suppose google published what they claim to be their source code
>>>>>>>>>and said its GPL'd. Now what? How do you know that its actually
>>>>>>>>>what they're running? Duplicate their 100,000 machine server farm

You are talking about correctness verifiability here, I guess. That has
always been
a tough nut. But, I am not talking about that. I am talking about those
strange things
that happen... Like what happened to George Bush, the word jew, etc, and
Page couldn't
explain why it was happening. (or didn't want to).

>>>>>>>>>and verify it? (yes, 100,000.) And if you're not happy with google
>>>>>>>>>what do you do? How does the source code help you?

Those 1 lac only store data. I am not talking about data. I am talking about
the softbrain
that sifts through it. I don't need to replicate their server farm, to do
that.

>>>>>>>>>Wake me up when hardware gets cheap enough for hobbyists to buy
>>>>>>>>>enough memory to store the whole web.

Yes, I agree with you. But, didn't you read that recent post where Bill
Gates went on record
saying Hardware will soon hit Zero Cost? And, by the way, that line is
self-negating.
You can't EVER have enough memory to store the whole web, because,
semantically analyzing
your sentence, the web is nothing but what is there in a million odd boxes
around the world.
And, so how can a box ever aspire to have everything including what it has
inside itself? :-)

>>>>>>>>>You say this is "decidedly non-decentralizable", yet the website
>>>>>>>>>you've pointed to below says that it is concerned exclusively with
>>>>>>>>>distributed efforts. I think it might be better to get some idea
>>>>>>>>>of what we're talking about first.

Yes, they only talk about it though. I said it was decidedly
non-decentralizable because,
like you say, it was hardware INTENSIVE, to make any sense. Software, being
the vapour
that it is, is so easily decentralized. Look at how Nasa is down to its
knees begging for
free-cpu-cycles from homepc guys for its seti search and protein folding?

>>>>>>>>>This is an issue of trust, not sofware; a social, not a technical
>>>>>>>>>concern. The only way out of your problem is for everyone to
operate
>>>>>>>>>their own search engine. Duh.

I beg to differ here. I don't think that is the only way out. (Correct me if
I am wrong).
I feel, once Google gets its game right, launches IPO, makes enough money
for three generations,
and sets up an exceptionally good file system and hardware-mirror-around the
world, it surely can
do a great good turn to the whole world (cyber/physical) by giving its
algorithm out! (Thereby
ensuring that no other search engine comes any nearer!!)

Don't you think so??

Rajendran.

From tuxkumar at yahoo.com  Fri Apr 23 08:17:22 2004
From: tuxkumar at yahoo.com (SaravanaKumar)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 13:47:22 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] Re: modprobe error
In-Reply-To: <c5vuec$2nc$1@sea.gmane.org>
References: <c5vuec$2nc$1@sea.gmane.org>
Message-ID: <c6ajev$89f$1@sea.gmane.org>

i added these lines to my modules.conf:

alias sound-slot-0 off
alias sound-service-0-0 off
alias sound-service-0-3 off

And no more errors like that. BTW i dont want sound.

Thanx google.
SK

From linux_lover at myrealbox.com  Fri Apr 23 09:40:35 2004
From: linux_lover at myrealbox.com (barani)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 03:40:35 -0600
Subject: [Ilugc] problem apache configuration
Message-ID: <1082713235.9f89f49clinux_lover@myrealbox.com>

Dear ILUGC users,
I am having some  problem in configuring apache server.When i tried to acce=
ss the file blast.cgi which is kept in /var/www/html/blast/ it says

"Forbidden
You don't have permission to access /blast/blast.cgi on this server."
1) i have included the following inboth httpd.conf and httpd2.conf
"
DocumentRoot /var/www/html
AddHandler cgi-script .cgi .pl
ScriptAlias /cgi-bin/ /var/www/html/cgi-bin/
<Directory /var/www/html/cgi-bin/>
AllowOverride AuthConfig
Options +ExecCGI FollowSymLinks
Order allow,deny
Allow from all
</Directory>"
2) i have given full permisssion for the files by chmod 777
3) the /etc/httpd/logs/error_log file says
[Thu Apr 22 08:39:18 2004] [error] [client 10.22.32.3] Options ExecCGI is o=
ff in this directory: /var/www/html/blast/blast.cgi, referer: http://10.2=
2.32.3/blast/blast.html

I have wasted almost a month finding the solution to this problem.
..I will be very grateful if anyone of you can help me in this regard. 

-- Barani
   IITKGP
Baranidharan P
Senior Project Assistant 
Bioinformatics Sub-DIC
Dept. of Biotechnology
Indian Institute of Technology
Kharagpur -721302

From hari at nmsworks.co.in  Fri Apr 23 10:04:24 2004
From: hari at nmsworks.co.in (Hari U)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 15:34:24 +0530 (IST)
Subject: [Ilugc] problem apache configuration
In-Reply-To: <1082713235.9f89f49clinux_lover@myrealbox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0404231524240.1594-100000@fileserver.nmsworks.co.in>

On Fri, 23 Apr 2004, barani wrote:

 
> "Forbidden
> You don't have permission to access /blast/blast.cgi on this server."

Mr barani enable the following entry in httpd.conf,then it will work
1) <IfModule mod_perl.c>
  Alias /perl/ /var/www/perl/
  <Location /perl>
    SetHandler perl-script
    PerlHandler Apache::Registry
    Options +ExecCGI
  </Location>
</IfModule>

2.another thing whatever your scripts copied into appropriate httpd home 
directory.
you will do above 2 tasks,it will work.



Rgds
U.Hari

From arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in  Fri Apr 23 13:12:07 2004

But perhaps I was not very polite, in which case I apologize.

Excuse me, but I'm not quite sure you have any idea what you're talking
about. The existence of googlebombing is the greatest testament to the 
NON-EVILNESS of google, and is free speech at its finest. Far from nobody
being able to explain how it happened, it is extremely well known how
pagerank works. The fact that google won't deviate from their published
algorithm even under political or other pressure says a lot about their
integrity. I'm sorry, but I'd suggest you read about these things before
spinning conspiracy theories. http://www.webmasterworld.com/ is a good
place to start.
 
> >>>>>>>>>and verify it? (yes, 100,000.) And if you're not happy with google

And as I said in my previous post, the softbrain or whatever is useless if
you aren't able to replicate the server farm.

> >>>>>>>>>enough memory to store the whole web.
> 
> Yes, I agree with you. But, didn't you read that recent post where Bill
> Gates went on record
> saying Hardware will soon hit Zero Cost? And, by the way, that line is

> semantically analyzing

> around the world.
> And, so how can a box ever aspire to have everything including what it has
> inside itself? :-)

Amazing logic. First, I didn't say a single box would have to store the 
entire web. Second, most of those zillions of webservers, which are 
hobbyist sites, have only a few megs of web content. Third, google already
has enough boxes to mirror the web, so I don't know what you're trying to 
prove.

From arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in  Fri Apr 23 14:34:20 2004
From: arvindn at meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in (Arvind Narayanan)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 20:04:20 +0530
Subject: [Ilugc] 1024 bit dsa key pair ??
In-Reply-To: <15086.192.76.54.22.1082729148.squirrel@www.tharayil.com>; from tom@tharayil.com on Fri, Apr 23, 2004 at 09:05:48AM -0500
References: <15086.192.76.54.22.1082729148.squirrel@www.tharayil.com>
Message-ID: <20040423200419.A19796@meenakshi.cs.iitm.ernet.in>

On Fri, Apr 23, 2004 at 09:05:48AM -0500, Tom Jose Tharayil wrote:
> I have seen the movie swordfish.....but this is stretching it...
> Is it usual to see a 1024 bit dsa key pair or am I seeing things ?
> just generated this on a solaris box.

Hi,

There are two kinds of cryptographic algorithms: single-key, or
symmetric algorithms and two-key or assymmetric algorithms. They
have different properties and are used for different purposes. 
There is no relation between the key sizes of the two.

Currently the standard for the former type is 128 bits, and for
the latter it is 1024 bits. I think that's the source of your
confusion.

I'm not familiar with the movie in question, but 128 bit symmetric
keys are currently *not* breakable (assuming, of course, that the
algorithm itself doesn't have weaknesses. But then any crypto 
algorithms shown in movies are unlikely to be more secure than rot13 ;-)

Useful link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_size

Arvind
-- 
Q: Do you ever think about quantum computing?  
Linus: I think that's a load of bull.
(From a Linux Lunacy cruise interview. After the presumptuous disparagement
of QC, Linus goes on to confuse it with DNA computing.)

>>Like what happened to George Bush, the word jew, etc, and Page
couldn't explain why it was happening. (or didn't want to).

Hmm..if I remember, Page said that he didn't mind such Google bombs. 

Now, I have to go with Arvind here..how are we gonna gain out of knowing
Google's PageRank algorithm? This is not a Linux kernel which you can
download and play around with. Lets say you do get the code..how is
anybody going to understand it without Google's data? We can just make
educated guesses..but that's what it'll be at the end of the day -
guesses.

But Google, on the other hand, stands to lose a lot. People like MSN,
AltaVista who have access to the same type of data can easily profit
from Google opening up its algorithms..and no one would know about it.


On a slightly unrelated note, I have always wondered whether it would be
possible to build a P2P search engine..basically have millions of users
spidering and indexing all the time. I guess that sounds more like a
grid-computing initiative, but I'm sure you understand what I mean.

Sriram

always been a tough nut. But, I am not talking about that. I am talking
about those strange things that happen... Like what happened to George
Bush, the word jew, etc, and Page couldn't explain why it was happening.
(or didn't want to).

>>>>>>>>>Wake me up when hardware gets cheap enough for hobbyists to buy

>>>>>>>>>enough memory to store the whole web.

Yes, I agree with you. But, didn't you read that recent post where Bill
Gates went on record saying Hardware will soon hit Zero Cost? And, by
the way, that line is self-negating. You can't EVER have enough memory
to store the whole web, because, semantically analyzing your sentence,
the web is nothing but what is there in a million odd boxes around the
world. And, so how can a box ever aspire to have everything including
what it has inside itself? :-)

>>>>>>>>>You say this is "decidedly non-decentralizable", yet the 
>>>>>>>>>website you've pointed to below says that it is concerned 
>>>>>>>>>exclusively with distributed efforts. I think it might be 
>>>>>>>>>better to get some idea of what we're talking about first.

non-decentralizable because, like you say, it was hardware INTENSIVE, to
make any sense. Software, being the vapour that it is, is so easily
decentralized. Look at how Nasa is down to its knees begging for
free-cpu-cycles from homepc guys for its seti search and protein
folding?

>>>>>>>>>This is an issue of trust, not sofware; a social, not a 
>>>>>>>>>technical concern. The only way out of your problem is for 
>>>>>>>>>everyone to
operate
>>>>>>>>>their own search engine. Duh.

me if I am wrong). I feel, once Google gets its game right, launches
IPO, makes enough money for three generations, and sets up an
exceptionally good file system and hardware-mirror-around the world, it
surely can do a great good turn to the whole world (cyber/physical) by
giving its algorithm out! (Thereby ensuring that no other search engine
comes any nearer!!)

Don't you think so??

Rajendran.




From cyborg4k at yahoo.com  Sat Apr 24 02:36:13 2004
From: cyborg4k at yahoo.com (Shaks)
Date: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 19:36:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [Ilugc] Volunteers? New man page doc project
Message-ID: <20040424023613.40086.qmail@web40103.mail.yahoo.com>

Hi!

I am working on a man page documentation project (on
my own) and would like to know if anyone would be
interested in joining me. Basically man pages don't
provide sufficient examples for the different command
options and I am writing illustrative examples for
each option with as many examples as possible.

This is basically for system/network administration
commands, but, we can expand the idea to other
commands as well.

For example, download at.1 (man page for "at" command)
file from here:
http://www.rit.edu/~sak5991/at.1

To view the man page, do:
#nroff -man -Tascii at.1 | less

Let me know if anyone will be interested in rewriting
the man pages with examples,

Thanks,

Shaks

Pray how you figured google is NON-EVIL? (and why CAPS ON?)

This article might be a good eye-opener:

http://www.searchenginejournal.com/index.php?p=448

<quote>
The proposal would offer  individuals large e-mail storage in exchange
for the ability to scan all private emails in order to insert ads that
might be related to the ongoing personal discussions. 

[snip]

Google  claims that computerized  scanning of  e-mails is  nothing new
because its service performs  some essential function as antivirus and
anti-spam  software,  which has  to  scan  e-mail  text regularly.  No
employee of the company actually reads the e-mail while doing so. 
</quote>

Given the  fact that  gmail wants  to read your  mails (or  atleast it
intended to read your mails at  some point of time before this privacy
issue  came up),  i would  certainly not  look at  it as  an anti-spam
measure. Infact  they would be spamming  me! (ok, its  not "spam". its
"ADs". Whatever,  I wouldn't  be comfortable with  an AD  on body-part
enhancement when I'm writing a mail to Dr.Mathrubhootham)

,----
| being able to explain how it  happened, it is extremely well known how
| pagerank  works.  The  fact  that  google  won't  deviate  from  their
| published algorithm even under political  or other pressure says a lot
| about their integrity.
`----

Really? How is it a "fact"  that google wont deviate frm its published
algorithm? I  dont want to sound  harsh, I cannot help  though: Do you
even  know if its  algorithm hasn't  changed /  has changed  since two
months?

,----
| I don't know if  this is a weak attempt at humor  or you are under the
| impression  that  we  live  in  a fairy-tale  world  where  companies,
| especially publicly traded ones, act out of philanthropic motives.
`----

Thats exactly  my point.  Google certainly does  some cool technology.
Its not  logical to assume that  google is NON-EVIL  because its doing
cool-technology. GMail certainly does not sound NON-EVIL to me.

cheers,

  -Suraj
